packages.name: Cython
packages.descl: Cython is a language that makes writing C extensions for the Python language as easy as Python itself. Cython is based on the well-known Pyrex, but supports more cutting edge functionality and optimizations.  Homepage: http://www.cython.org/

packages.name: GConf
packages.descl: GConf is a configuration database system designed for the GNOME project and applications based on GTK+. It is conceptually similar to the Windows registry.  For information, see: http://projects.gnome.org/gconf/

packages.name: Greybird
packages.descl: Greybird theme is a desktop theme suite for Xfce.  Homepage: https://github.com/shimmerproject/Greybird

packages.name: LibRaw
packages.descs: LibRaw (library for decoding raw digital photos)
packages.descl: LibRaw is a library for reading RAW files from digital photo cameras (CRW/CR2, NEF, RAF, DNG, MOS, KDC, DCR, etc, virtually all RAW formats are supported). It pays special attention to correct retrieval of data required for subsequent RAW conversion. The library is intended for embedding in RAW converters, data analyzers, and other programs using RAW files as the initial data.  Homepage: https://www.libraw.org/

packages.name: M2Crypto
packages.descl: M2Crypto is a crypto and SSL toolkit for Python. It includes: - RSA, DSA, DH, HMACs, message digests, symmetric ciphers (e.g. AES) - SSL functionality to implement clients and servers - HTTPS extensions to Python's httplib, urllib, and xmlrpclib - Unforgeable HMAC'ing AuthCookies for web session management - FTP/TLS client and server, S/MIME v2, ZServerSSL, ZSmime  Homepage: https://gitlab.com/m2crypto/m2crypto

packages.name: MPlayer
packages.descl: MPlayer is a movie player for Linux. It plays most MPEG, VOB, AVI, Ogg/OGM, VIVO, ASF/WMA/WMV, QT/MOV/MP4, FLI, RM, NuppelVideo, YUV4MPEG, FILM, RoQ, PVA files, supported by many native, XAnim, and Win32 DLL codecs. You can watch VideoCD, SVCD, DVD, 3ivx, DivX 3/4/5 and even WMV movies, too (without the avifile library). MPlayer supports 10 types of subtitles formats: VobSub, MicroDVD, SubRip, SubViewer, Sami, VPlayer, RT, SSA, AQTitle, MPsub.  Homepage for MPlayer is http://www.mplayerhq.hu/

packages.name: Mako
packages.descl: Mako is a template library written in Python. It provides a familiar, non-XML syntax which compiles into Python modules for maximum performance. Mako's syntax and API borrows from the best ideas of many others, including Django and Jinja2 templates, Cheetah, Myghty, and Genshi. Conceptually, Mako is an embedded Python language.  Homepage: http://www.makotemplates.org

packages.name: ModemManager
packages.descl: ModemManager provides a unified high level API for communicating with mobile broadband modems.  Homepage: https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/ModemManager

packages.name: NetworkManager
packages.descl: The point of NetworkManager is to make networking configuration and setup as painless and automatic as possible. NetworkManager sets IP addresses, default routes, associating with wireless access points or wired LANs, and other network configuration settings in a simple, automated fashion (manual overrides are still possible).  Home page: http://projects.gnome.org/NetworkManager/

packages.name: NetworkManager-openvpn
packages.descl: NetworkManager attempts to keep an active network connection available at all times. This applet provides OpenVPN Support for NetworkManager.  Homepage: https://github.com/GNOME/NetworkManager-openvpn

packages.name: OpenCC
packages.descl: Open Chinese Convert is an opensource project for conversion between Traditional Chinese and Simplified Chinese, supporting character- level conversion, phrase-level conversion, variant conversion and regional idioms among Mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong.  Homepage: http://OpenCC.byvoid.com/

packages.name: PyQt5
packages.descl: PyQt5 is a set of Python bindings for Trolltech's Qt5 application framework and runs on all platforms supported by Qt5.  Homepage: http://www.riverbankcomputing.co.uk/software/pyqt/

packages.name: QScintilla
packages.descs: QScintilla (Qt port of the Scintilla C++ editor control)
packages.descl: QScintilla includes features especially useful when editing and debugging source code. These include support for syntax styling, error indicators, code completion, and call tips. The selection margin can contain markers like those used in debuggers to indicate breakpoints and the current line. Styling choices are more open than with many editors, allowing the use of proportional fonts, bold and italics, multiple foreground and background colours, and multiple fonts.

packages.name: QtAV
packages.descl: QtAV is a multimedia playback framework based on Qt and FFmpeg. Some components in QtAV are designed to be extensible.  Homepage: http://qtav.org

packages.name: SDL2
packages.descl: Simple DirectMedia Layer is a cross-platform development library designed to provide low-level access to audio, keyboard, mouse, joystick, and graphics hardware ia via OpenGL. It is used by video playback software, emulators, and games.  Homepage: http://www.libsdl.org

packages.name: SDL2_gfx
packages.descs: SDL2_gfx (SDL2 graphics primitives and surface functions)
packages.descl: The SDL2_gfx library provides the basic drawing functions such as lines, circles or polygons.  Homepage: http://www.ferzkopp.net/Software/SDL2_gfx/Docs/html/

packages.name: SDL2_image
packages.descl: This is a simple library to load images of various formats as SDL surfaces. This library supports BMP, PNM (PPM/PGM/PBM), XPM, LBM, PCX, GIF, JPEG, PNG, TGA, and TIFF formats.  Homepage: http://www.libsdl.org/projects/SDL_image/

packages.name: SDL2_mixer
packages.descl: SDL_mixer is a simple multi-channel audio mixer library. It supports any number of simultaneously playing channels of 16 bit stereo audio, plus a single channel of music.  Homepage: http://www.libsdl.org/projects/SDL_mixer/

packages.name: SDL2_net
packages.descl: This is an example portable network library for use with SDL.  Homepage: http://www.libsdl.org/projects/SDL_net/

packages.name: SDL2_ttf
packages.descl: This library allows you to use TrueType fonts to render text in SDL2 applications.  Homepage: http://www.libsdl.org/projects/SDL_ttf/

packages.name: a2ps
packages.descl: GNU a2ps is an Any to PostScript filter. Of course it processes plain text files, but also pretty prints quite a few popular programming languages.  Homepage: https://www.gnu.org/software/a2ps/

packages.name: a52dec
packages.descl: a52dec is a test program for liba52. It decodes ATSC A/52 streams and also includes a demultiplexer for mpeg-1 and mpeg-2 program streams. This package also includes liba52, which is a free library for decoding ATSC A/52 streams. The A/52 standard is used in a variety of applications, including digital television and DVD. It is also known as AC-3.  Homepage: http://liba52.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: aaa_base
packages.descl: Sets up the empty directory tree for Slackware and adds an email to root's mailbox welcoming them to Linux. :)  This package should be installed first, and never uninstalled.

packages.name: aaa_glibc-solibs
packages.descl: This package contains the shared libraries, binaries, and support files required to run most Linux applications linked with glibc.

packages.name: aaa_libraries
packages.descs: aaa_libraries (shared libraries needed by many programs)
packages.descl: This is a collection of shared libraries needed to run Linux programs. These libraries are gathered from other Slackware packages and are intended to give a minimal initial set of libraries.

packages.name: aaa_terminfo
packages.descs: aaa_terminfo (a basic collection of terminfo entries)
packages.descl: This is a starter set of files from the terminfo database, which should be enough in most cases. The complete set (from which this is derived) can be found in the ncurses package.  The terminfo database describes the characteristics of terminals, so don't try to log in without this package. :-)

packages.name: aalib
packages.descl: __111llvl+' __...._   +1lv11=. AA-lib is an ASCII art graphics     _11vllvlv+  =vlvlvl1=  /1vlvv1i=_ library. Internally, the AA-lib    _vvllvlvlv=  -+vlvlvlvlvlvlvlvdvl=_ API is similar to other graphics  _:lvlvlvlvlv=.    --^-^1lvlvlrlvv1s libraries, but it renders the     =llvlvvlvlvv11lvl=....  -lvlevlvlvv the output into ASCII art (like   =lvlvlvlvll-^+1vv11111v_  vlkllvllvl the example to the right :^)      =lvlvlvlvl1   +1vv1v1lv  _llvlvlvlvl The developers of AA-lib are       +1lv |vlvl'    -^-^-   _1olvlvlvlv' Jan Hubicka, Thomas A. K. Kjaer,   -1vl |lvlvlvlvlvlvlvlvv1vlvlvlvlv+. Tim Newsome, and Kamil Toman.       +1 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^vlv- -+uvlvlvlvlvlvlvlvlvlvlvlvl+_ -vlvlvlvlvlvlvlvllvlvl-'

packages.name: accountsservice
packages.descs: accountsservice (D-Bus interface for user account query)
packages.descl: AccountsService is a D-Bus service for accessing the list of user accounts and information attached to those accounts.  Homepage: https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/AccountsService/

packages.name: acct
packages.descl: This is a set of utilities which reports and summarizes data about user connect times and process execution statistics. To activate process accounting, create the log file (touch /var/log/pacct), and then use the accton command to start it (accton /var/log/pacct). Be aware that the log file can grow to be quite large.  The GNU process accounting utilities were written by Noel Cragg and the software is currently maintained by Ciaran O'Riordan, Manuel A. Fernandez Montecelo, and Tim Schmielau.

packages.name: acl
packages.descs: acl (tools for using POSIX Access Control Lists)
packages.descl: This package contains a set of tools and libraries for manipulating POSIX Access Control Lists. POSIX Access Control Lists (defined in POSIX 1003.1e draft standard 17) are used to define more fine-grained discretionary access rights for files and directories.  Homepage: http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/acl

packages.name: acpid
packages.descl: Most modern computers support the Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) standard to allow intelligent power management. This package contains acpid, which is the user-space daemon needed in order to make the Linux ACPI support completely functional.  ACPI must be compiled into the kernel to run acpid.  Homepage: http://sourceforge.net/projects/acpid2/

packages.name: adwaita-icon-theme
packages.descl: A set of default icons used by many GTK+ applications.

packages.name: akonadi
packages.descl: Akonadi is an extensible cross-desktop storage service for PIM data and meta data providing concurrent read, write, and query access. It will provide a unique desktop wide object identification and retrieval.  Homepage: http://www.kdepim.org/akonadi/

packages.name: akonadi-calendar
packages.descl: Akonadi Calendar provides jobs, models and other helpers to make working with events and calendars through Akonadi easier.

packages.name: akonadi-calendar-tools
packages.descs: akonadi-calendar-tools (CLI tools to manage Akonadi calendars)
packages.descl: Console applications and utilities for managing calendars in Akonadi.

packages.name: akonadi-contacts
packages.descl: Akonadi Contacts contains libraries and daemons to implement Contact Management in Akonadi.

packages.name: akonadi-import-wizard
packages.descl: Assistant to import PIM data from other mail clients to KMail.

packages.name: akonadi-mime
packages.descl: akonadi-mime contains libraries and daemons that provide jobs, models and other helpers to make working with emails through Akonadi easier.

packages.name: akonadi-notes
packages.descl: Akonadi Notes is a library that effectively bridges the type-agnostic API of the Akonadi client libraries and the domain-specific KMime library. It provides a helper class for note attachments and for wrapping notes into KMime::Message objects.

packages.name: akonadi-search
packages.descl: Akonadi Search contains libraries and daemons to implement Xapian based indexing and query infrastructure for Akonadi.

packages.name: akonadiconsole
packages.descl: Akonadi Console is a tool for developers working with Akonadi or on Akonadi itself. It provides a GUI for managing agents and resources, retrieving, checking and even manipulating data, monitoring communication between Akonadi server and its clients, as well as convenience access to the database used by the server.

packages.name: akregator
packages.descl: KDE feed reader.

packages.name: alkimia
packages.descl: Alkimia is a library used by KDE Finance applications, like Kmymoney.

packages.name: alpine
packages.descs: alpine (Alternatively Licensed Program for Internet News and Email)
packages.descl: Alpine is a fast, easy to use email client that is suitable for both the inexperienced email user as well as for the most demanding of power users. Alpine is based on the Pine(R) Message System, which was also developed at the University of Washington. Alpine can be learned by exploration and the use of context-sensitive help. The user experience is highly customizable through the use of the Alpine Setup command.  Homepage: https://repo.or.cz/alpine.git

packages.name: alsa-lib
packages.descl: The Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) provides audio and MIDI functionality to the Linux operating system. This is the ALSA library (libasound) which is used by audio applications.  For more information, see http://alsa-project.org

packages.name: alsa-oss
packages.descs: alsa-oss (library/wrapper to use OSS programs with ALSA)
packages.descl: The Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) provides audio and MIDI functionality to the Linux operating system. OSS (Open Sound System) is an older sound system for Linux that ALSA is replacing. Using the aoss wrapper you can use programs that only support OSS with ALSA without having to load the OSS compatibility kernel modules.

packages.name: alsa-plugins
packages.descl: The Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) provides audio and MIDI functionality to the Linux operating system. This package includes plugins for ALSA.  Website: http://www.alsa-project.org

packages.name: alsa-utils
packages.descl: The Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) provides audio and MIDI functionality to the Linux operating system. This package contains command line audio utilities for use with ALSA: alsactl        (manage soundcard settings) arecord/aplay  (capture and play audio) amixer         (adjust mixer settings from the command line) alsamixer      (an ncurses-based console mixer)  For more information, see http://alsa-project.org

packages.name: amp
packages.descl: amp (Audio Mpeg Player) is a command-line MPEG audio decoder (MP3 player). It works with both MPEG1 and MPEG2 audio streams (except for the multichannel extensions defined in MPEG2), layers 2 and 3.

packages.name: analitza
packages.descl: The analitza library will let you add mathematical features to your program.  Homepage: https://projects.kde.org/projects/kde/kdeedu/analitza

packages.name: anthy
packages.descs: anthy (a system for Japanese input method)
packages.descl: Anthy is a library for Japanese text input. It converts Hiragana text to Kana Kanji mixed text.  anthy home: http://anthy.sourceforge.jp/

packages.name: appres
packages.descl: The appres program prints the resources seen by an application (or subhierarchy of an application) with the specified class and instance names. It can be used to determine which resources a particular program will load.

packages.name: apr
packages.descl: The mission of the Apache Portable Runtime (APR) is to provide a free library of C data structures and routines, forming a system portability layer to as many operating systems as possible.

packages.name: apr-util
packages.descl: The mission of the Apache Portable Runtime (APR) is to provide a free library of C data structures and routines, forming a system portability layer to as many operating systems as possible.  This package contains additional utility interfaces for APR; including support for XML, LDAP, database interfaces, URI parsing, and more.

packages.name: argon2
packages.descl: This is the reference C implementation of Argon2, the password-hashing function that won the Password Hashing Competition (see https://password-hashing.net).  Argon2 is a password-hashing function that summarizes the state of the art in the design of memory-hard functions and can be used for credential storage, key derivation, or other applications.  Homepage: https://github.com/P-H-C/phc-winner-argon2

packages.name: ark
packages.descl: This is KDE's application to work with compressed archives.

packages.name: artikulate
packages.descl: Artikulate is a pronunciation trainer, which helps in improving and perfecting pronunciation skills. Learners train their pronunciation by recording their own voices and comparing them to native speaker recordings. Artikulate is part of the KDE Education Project.

packages.name: aspell
packages.descl: GNU Aspell is a spell checker designed to eventually replace Ispell. It can either be used as a library or as an independent spell checker.

packages.name: aspell-en
packages.descl: GNU Aspell 0.60 English Dictionary Package.

packages.name: at
packages.descl: at and batch read shell commands from standard input (or a specified file) storing them as a job to be scheduled for execution at a later time.  The 'at' command was written by David Parsons and Thomas Koenig.  Homepage: http://blog.calhariz.com/tag/at

packages.name: at-spi2-atk
packages.descl: The At-Spi2 Atk package contains a library that bridges ATK to the At-Spi2 D-Bus service.

packages.name: at-spi2-core
packages.descs: at-spi2-core (Assistive Technology Service Provider Interface core)
packages.descl: The At-Spi2 Core package is a part of the GNOME Accessibility Project. It provides a service provider interface for the assistive technologies available on the GNOME platform and a library against which applications can be linked.

packages.name: atk
packages.descl: atk is a library of accessibility functions that is used by the GTK+-2 toolkit.

packages.name: atkmm
packages.descl: atkmm is the C++ binding for the ATK library. This module is part of the GNOME C++ bindings effort.  Homepage: http://www.gtkmm.org/

packages.name: attica
packages.descl: Attica is a Qt library that implements the freedesktop.org specification for the Open Collaboration Services API version 1.4. It grants easy access to the services such as querying information about persons and contents.

packages.name: attr
packages.descs: attr (tools for using extended attributes on filesystems)
packages.descl: This package contains a set of tools for manipulating extended attributes (name:value pairs associated permanently with files and directories) on filesystem objects, and the library and header files needed to develop programs which make use of extended attributes. Extended attributes are used to provide additional functionality to a filesystem. For example, Access Control Lists (ACLs) are implemented using extended attributes.  Homepage: http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/attr

packages.name: audacious
packages.descl: Audacious is a media player, based on Beep Media Player, which is in turn based on the X Multimedia System (XMMS). It is used to play audio and other kinds of media files. By default Audacious can play MPEG audio, Ogg Vorbis, RIFF wav, most module formats, and a few other formats. Audacious can be extended through plugins to play a number of other audio and video formats.  Homepage: http://www.audacious-media-player.org

packages.name: audacious-plugins
packages.descs: audacious-plugins (Plugins used by the Audacious media player)
packages.descl: This is a collection of plugins for Audacious to support additional media formats.  Homepage: http://www.audacious-media-player.org

packages.name: audiocd-kio
packages.descl: Audiocd kio slave.

packages.name: audiofile
packages.descl: Audiofile is a library to handle various audio file formats, and is used by the esound daemon. You can also use it to develop your own audiofile applications.

packages.name: autoconf
packages.descl: GNU autoconf is an extensible package of m4 macros that produce shell scripts to automatically configure software source code packages. These scripts can adapt the packages to many kinds of UNIX-like systems without manual user intervention. Autoconf creates a configuration script for a package from a template file that lists the operating system features that the package can use, in the form of m4 macro calls. You must install the 'm4' package to be able to use autoconf.

packages.name: autoconf-archive
packages.descl: The GNU Autoconf Archive is a large collection of useful and tested macros for GNU Autoconf that have been contributed as free software by friendly supporters of the cause from all over the Internet. This package contains the complete content of the archive.  Homepage: https://www.gnu.org/software/autoconf-archive/

packages.name: autofs
packages.descl: autofs is a kernel-based automounter for Linux. It performs a job similar to amd(8) but relies on a small stub of kernel code instead of pretending to be an NFS server. The result is simpler code, better reliability, and much faster operation in the common case (everything already mounted.)

packages.name: automake
packages.descl: This is Automake, a Makefile generator. It was inspired by the 4.4BSD make and include files, but aims to be portable and to conform to the GNU standards for Makefile variables and targets. Automake is a Perl script. The input files are called Makefile.am. The output files are called Makefile.in; they are intended for use with Autoconf. Automake requires certain things to be done in your configure.in. You must install the 'm4' and 'perl' packages to be able to use automake.

packages.name: babl
packages.descl: babl is a dynamic, any to any, pixel format translation library.  It allows converting between different methods of storing pixels known as pixel formats that have with different bitdepths and other data representations, color models and component permutations.  A vocabulary to formulate new pixel formats from existing primitives is provided as well as the framework to add new color models and data types.

packages.name: baloo
packages.descs: baloo (framework for searching and managing metadata)
packages.descl: Baloo is a framework for searching and managing metadata. Baloo focuses on providing a very small memory footprint along with extremely fast searching. It also supports storing additional file based metadata via extended attributes.

packages.name: baloo-widgets
packages.descl: Baloo is a framework for searching and managing metadata. Baloo-widgets contains widgets for use with Baloo.

packages.name: bash
packages.descl: The GNU Bourne-Again SHell. Bash is a sh-compatible command interpreter that executes commands read from the standard input or from a file. Bash also incorporates useful features from the Korn and C shells (ksh and csh). Bash is ultimately intended to be a conformant implementation of the IEEE Posix Shell and Tools specification (IEEE Working Group 1003.2).  Bash must be present for the system to boot properly.

packages.name: bc
packages.descl: bc is an arbitrary precision numeric processing language. Syntax is similar to C, but differs in many substantial areas. It supports interactive execution of statements. bc is a utility included in the POSIX P1003.2/D11 draft standard.  The GNU version of bc was written by Philip A. Nelson.

packages.name: bdftopcf
packages.descs: bdftopcf (font compiler for the X server and font server)
packages.descl: Fonts in Portable Compiled Format can be read by any architecture, although the file is structured to allow one particular architecture to read them directly without reformatting. This allows fast reading on the appropriate machine, but the files are still portable (but read more slowly) on other machines.

packages.name: beforelight
packages.descl: The beforelight program is a sample implementation of a screen saver for X servers supporting the MIT-SCREEN-SAVER extension. It is only recommended for use as a code sample, as it does not include features such as screen locking or configurability.

packages.name: biff+comsat
packages.descl: Comsat is the server process which receives reports of incoming mail and notifies users if they have requested this service. 'biff' is the program that requests comsat service 'biff y', and may be placed in a user's startup file if they'd like to hear a beep and trash their console with each new piece of junk mail. ;-)  Biff was the name of Heidi Stettner's dog, who barked when the mailman came. Biff was well known to many of the early BSD developers living in Evans Hall at U.C. Berkeley.

packages.name: bin
packages.descl: The bin package is a collection of miscellaneous command-line utilities. Some of these (such as 'tempfile') are used in system scripts.

packages.name: bind
packages.descl: The named daemon and support utilities such as dig, host, and nslookup. Sample configuration files for running a simple caching nameserver are included. Documentation for advanced name server setup can be found in /usr/doc/bind-9.x.x/.

packages.name: binutils
packages.descl: Binutils is a collection of binary utilities. It includes 'as' (the portable GNU assembler), 'ld' (the GNU linker), and other utilities for creating and working with binary programs.  These utilities are REQUIRED to compile C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, and most other programming languages.

packages.name: bison
packages.descl: GNU Bison is a general-purpose parser generator that converts a grammar description for an LALR(1) context-free grammar into a C program to parse that grammar. Bison is upward compatible with Yacc: all properly-written Yacc grammars ought to work with Bison with no change. Anyone familiar with Yacc should be able to use Bison with little trouble.  Homepage: https://www.gnu.org/software/bison/

packages.name: bitmap
packages.descs: bitmap (X bitmap (XBM) editor and converter utilities)
packages.descl: The bitmap package includes the bitmap, bmtoa, and atobm programs.

packages.name: blackbox
packages.descl: Blackbox is that fast, light window manager you have been looking for without all those annoying library dependencies.  Also included in this package is the bbkeys utility for controlling keyboard shortcut commands from within Blackbox.  Homepage: https://github.com/bbidulock/blackboxwm

packages.name: blinken
packages.descl: Blinken is a memory enhancement game for KDE.

packages.name: bluedevil
packages.descl: BlueDevil is the bluetooth stack for KDE.  Homepage: http://www.afiestas.org/

packages.name: blueman
packages.descl: Blueman is a GTK+ Bluetooth Manager for tasks such as:  - Connecting to 3G/EDGE/GPRS via DUN profile. - Connecting to/Creating bluetooth networks - Connecting to input and audio devices - Sending/Receiving/Browsing files via OBEX - Pairing  Homepage: https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman

packages.name: bluez
packages.descl: Bluez is the Bluetooth stack for Linux, allowing Bluetooth adaptors and devices to be used with Linux. This package contains the Bluez libraries, utilities, and other support files.  Homepage: http://www.bluez.org

packages.name: bluez-firmware
packages.descl: The bluez-firmware package contains firmware needed by various chipsets to support Bluetooth(TM) on Linux.  For more info, visit: http://www.bluez.org

packages.name: bluez-qt
packages.descs: bluez-qt (Qt wrapper for BlueZ 5 DBus API)
packages.descl: BluezQt is a library for communication with BlueZ system and session daemons. Manager class is used to communicate with system daemon org.bluez. ObexManager class is used to communicate with session daemon org.bluez.obex.  Homepage: https://projects.kde.org/projects/frameworks/bluez-qt

packages.name: bomber
packages.descl: Bomber is a single player arcade game. The player is invading various cities in a plane that is decreasing in height. The goal of the game is to destroy all the buildings and advance to the next level. Each level gets a bit harder by increasing the speed of the plane and the height of the buildings.

packages.name: boost
packages.descl: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries. The emphasis is on libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. One goal is to establish 'existing practice' and provide reference implementations so that the Boost libraries are suitable for eventual standardization.  Homepage: https://www.boost.org/

packages.name: bootp
packages.descl: This is an enhanced version of the CMU BOOTP server which was derived from the original BOOTP server created by Bill Croft at Stanford. BOOTP allows a network administrator to setup networking information for clients via an /etc/bootptab on a server so that the clients can automatically get their networking information.

packages.name: bovo
packages.descl: Bovo is a Gomoku ('five points' in Japanese) like game for two players, where the opponents alternate in placing their respective pictogram on the game board. Also known as: Connect Five, Five in a row, X and O, Naughts and Crosses.

packages.name: bpe
packages.descl: bpe is a simple, screen-oriented editor for searching and editing ordinary files in either ASCII or hexadecimal modes.  bpe was written by Andreas Pleschutznig. Bill Davidsen contributed additional features, as did Ralphe Neill (the current maintainer).

packages.name: breeze
packages.descl: Artwork, styles and assets for the Breeze visual style for the Plasma Desktop.

packages.name: breeze-grub
packages.descl: Breeze theme for GRUB.

packages.name: breeze-gtk
packages.descs: breeze-gtk (Breeze widget theme for GTK 2 and 3)
packages.descl: Breeze widget theme for GTK 2 and 3.

packages.name: breeze-icons
packages.descs: breeze-icons (Breeze icon themes for KDE Plasma)
packages.descl: Breeze icon themes for KDE Plasma.  Homepage: https://projects.kde.org/projects/kde/workspace/breeze

packages.name: bridge-utils
packages.descl: This package contains utilities for configuring Linux Ethernet bridges. The Linux Ethernet bridge can be used for connecting multiple Ethernet devices together. The connecting is fully transparent. Hosts connected to one Ethernet device see hosts connected through a bridge to the other Ethernet devices directly.  bridge-utils was written by Stephen Hemminger and Lennert Buytenhek.

packages.name: brotli
packages.descl: Brotli is a general purpose lossless compression algorithm that compresses data using a combination of a modern variant of the LZ77 algorithm, Huffman coding, and second order context modeling, with a compression ratio comparable to the best currently available general purpose compression methods. It is similar in speed with deflate but offers more dense compression.  Homepage: https://github.com/google/brotli/

packages.name: bsd-finger
packages.descl: The finger displays information about the system users. Finger displays the user's login name, real name, terminal name and write status (as a ``*'' after the terminal name if write permission is denied), idle time, login time, office location and office phone number.  As fingerd leaks semi-private information about your machine's usernames and other data, fingerd should be used with caution. Allow machines on a need-to-know basis.

packages.name: bsd-games
packages.descl: Games that go in /usr/games: adventure arithmetic atc backgammon banner battlestar bcd caesar canfield cfscores countmail cribbage dab factor fortune go-fish gomoku hack hangman hunt mille monop morse number phantasia pig pom ppt primes quiz rain random robots rot13 sail snake snscore teachgammon trek wargames worm worms wtf wump  Adds a call to 'fortune' to /etc/profile.d/ so that users will get a fortune message when they log in.

packages.name: btrfs-progs
packages.descl: Btrfs is a new copy on write filesystem for Linux aimed at implementing advanced features while focusing on fault tolerance, repair and easy administration. Initially developed by Oracle, Btrfs is licensed under the GPL and open for contribution from anyone.  Homepage: http://btrfs.wiki.kernel.org

packages.name: bzip2
packages.descl: Bzip2 compresses files using the Burrows-Wheeler block sorting text compression algorithm, and Huffman coding. Compression is generally considerably better than that achieved by more conventional LZ77/LZ78- based compressors, and approaches the performance of the PPM family of statistical compressors.  Julian Seward <jseward@acm.org> is the author of bzip2.

packages.name: c-ares
packages.descl: This is c-ares, an asynchronous resolver library. It is intended for applications which need to perform DNS queries without blocking, or need to perform multiple DNS queries in parallel. The primary examples of such applications are servers which communicate with multiple clients and programs with graphical user interfaces.  Homepage: https://c-ares.haxx.se/

packages.name: ca-certificates
packages.descl: This package includes PEM files of CA certificates to allow SSL-based applications to check for the authenticity of SSL connections.

packages.name: cairo
packages.descl: Cairo is a vector graphics library designed to provide high-quality display and print output. Cairo is designed to produce identical output on all output media while taking advantage of display hardware acceleration when available (eg. through the X Render Extension or OpenGL).  Homepage: https://cairographics.org

packages.name: cairomm
packages.descs: cairomm (C++ wrapper for the cairo graphics library)
packages.descl: cairomm is a C++ wrapper for the cairo graphics library. It offers all the power of cairo with an interface familiar to C++ developers, including use of the Standard Template Library where it makes sense.  Homepage: http://cairographics.org/cairomm/

packages.name: calendarsupport
packages.descl: The package contains KDE PIM calendar support library.

packages.name: calligra
packages.descl: Calligra office productivity applications. Included are a word processor, spreadsheet, presentation program, chart and graph creator, vector graphics tool, database report creator, flowcharting program, integrated data management program, a pixel graphics editor, a mathematical formula editor, and Calligra Workspace (a combination of all of the above).  Homepage: http://calligra-suite.org/

packages.name: calligraplan
packages.descl: Calligra Plan is a project management application. It is intended for managing moderately large projects with multiple resources.  Homepage: http://www.calligra-suite.org/

packages.name: cantor
packages.descl: Cantor is a frontend to several existing mathematical software such as R, Sage and Maxima. Cantor offers a worksheet as a nice GUI for all those backends and is not targeted to kids but to scientists.

packages.name: ccache
packages.descl: ccache is a compiler cache. It speeds up re-compilation of C/C++ code by caching previous compiles and detecting when the same compile is being done again.  ccache was written by Andrew Tridgell.  Homepage: https://ccache.samba.org/

packages.name: cdparanoia
packages.descl: cdparanoia is a Compact Disc Digital Audio (CDDA) extraction tool, commonly known on the net as a 'ripper'. It reads digital audio data from a Compact Disc and saves it to sound files. cdparanoia has been designed to read correct audio data even using cheap CD-ROM drives prone to misalignment, frame jitter and loss of streaming. cdparanoia will also read and repair data from CDs that have been damaged in some way.

packages.name: cdrdao
packages.descl: cdrdao burns proper disc-at-once (DAO) audio discs. In DAO mode the disc is written in one shot, so you don't have to have irritating 2 second gaps interrupting a live recording.

packages.name: cdrtools
packages.descl: Tools for mastering and writing compact discs.  cdda2wav - CD audio sampling utility. cdrecord - burn discs in most ATAPI and SCSI CD-R drives. mkisofs  - create ISO9660/HFS/Joliet CD-ROM images. mkzftree - compress a file tree to make a compressed CD-ROM.

packages.name: cervisia
packages.descl: cervisia is a graphical frontend for CVS.

packages.name: cfitsio
packages.descl: cfitsio is a library of ANSI C routines for reading and writing FITS format data files. A set of Fortran-callable wrapper routines is also included.  Homepage: http://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/fitsio

packages.name: check
packages.descl: Check is a unit test framework for C. It features a simple interface for defining unit tests, putting little in the way of the developer. Tests are run in a separate address space, so Check can catch both assertion failures and code errors that cause segmentation faults or other signals. The output from unit tests can be used within source code editors and IDEs.  Homepage: https://libcheck.github.io/check

packages.name: chmlib
packages.descl: chmlib is a small library designed for accessing MS ITSS files. The ITSS file format is used for Microsoft Html Help files (.chm), which have been the predominant medium for software documentation from Microsoft during the past several years, having superseded the previously used .hlp file format.  Homepage: http://www.jedrea.com/chmlib/

packages.name: cifs-utils
packages.descl: This is the release version of cifs-utils, a package of utilities for doing and managing mounts of the Linux CIFS filesystem. The in-kernel CIFS filesystem is generally the preferred method for mounting SMB/CIFS shares on Linux. This filesystem relies on a set of user-space tools that were originally part of Samba, but have now been split off into this separate package.  Home page: http://wiki.samba.org/index.php/LinuxCIFS_utils

packages.name: cldr-emoji-annotation
packages.descl: This package provides the emoji annotation file by language in CLDR.  Homepage: https://github.com/fujiwarat/cldr-emoji-annotation

packages.name: clisp
packages.descl: Common Lisp is a high-level, general-purpose programming language. GNU CLISP is a Common Lisp implementation by Bruno Haible of Karlsruhe University and Michael Stoll of Munich University, both in Germany. It mostly supports the Lisp described in the ANSI Common Lisp standard. The user interface comes in German, English, French, Spanish, Dutch and Russian. GNU CLISP includes an interpreter, a compiler, a debugger, a large subset of CLOS, a foreign language interface and a socket interface. An X11 interface is available through CLX and Garnet.

packages.name: clucene
packages.descl: CLucene is a C++ port of Lucene. It is a high-performance, full-featured text search engine written in C++.  Homepage: http://clucene.sourceforge.net

packages.name: cmake
packages.descl: CMake is used to control the software process using simple platform and compiler independent configuration files. CMake generates native makefiles and workspaces that can be used in the compiler environment of your choice.  Homepage: http://www.cmake.org

packages.name: compiz
packages.descl: Compiz is an OpenGL compositing manager that uses GLX_EXT_texture_from_pixmap for binding redirected top-level windows to texture objects. It has a flexible plug-in system and it is designed to run well on most graphics hardware.  Homepage: https://github.com/compiz-reloaded/compiz

packages.name: conntrack-tools
packages.descl: The conntrack-tools are a set of userspace tools that allow system administrators to interact with the Connection Tracking System (the module that provides stateful packet inspection for iptables).  The conntrack-tools include the userspace daemon conntrackd and the command line interface conntrack.  Homepage: https://www.netfilter.org/projects/conntrack-tools

packages.name: coreutils
packages.descl: These are the GNU core utilities, the basic command line programs such as 'mkdir', 'ls', and 'rm' that are needed for the system to run. This package is the union of the GNU fileutils, sh-utils, and textutils packages. Most of these programs have significant advantages over their Unix counterparts, such as greater speed, additional options, and fewer arbitrary limits.

packages.name: cpio
packages.descl: This is GNU cpio, a program to manage archives of files. This package also includes mt, a tape drive control program. cpio copies files into or out of a cpio or tar archive, which is a file that contains other files plus information about them, such as their pathname, owner, timestamps, and access permissions. The archive can be another file on the disk, a magnetic tape, or a pipe.

packages.name: cpufrequtils
packages.descl: The cpufrequtils package makes access to the Linux kernel CPUfreq subsystem easier for users and cpufreq userspace tools. It contains a library used by other programs (libcpufreq), and command line tools to determine current CPUfreq settings and to modify them.  Dominik Brodowski is the cpufrequtils maintainer.  Homepage: http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/kernel/cpufreq/

packages.name: cracklib
packages.descl: CrackLib is a library which may be used in a passwd-like program to prevent users from choosing passwords that could be easily guessed. This package is an updated and modernized distribution of CrackLib as previously released by Alec Muffett.  Homepage: https://github.com/cracklib/cracklib

packages.name: crda
packages.descl: This is the Central Regulatory Domain Agent for Linux. It serves one purpose: tell the Linux kernel what to enforce. In essence, it is a udev helper for communication between the kernel and userspace.  You only need to run this manually for debugging purposes.  Homepage: http://wireless.kernel.org

packages.name: cryfs
packages.descl: CryFS encrypts your files, so you can safely store them anywhere. It works well together with cloud services.  Homepage: https://www.cryfs.org

packages.name: cryptopp
packages.descl: Crypto++ Library is a free C++ class library of cryptographic schemes. See http://www.cryptopp.com/ for a list of supported algorithms. One purpose of Crypto++ is to act as a repository of public domain (not copyrighted) source code. Although the library is copyrighted as a compilation, the individual files in it are in the public domain.  Homepage: http://www.cryptopp.com/

packages.name: cryptsetup
packages.descs: cryptsetup (utility for setting up encrypted filesystems)
packages.descl: LUKS is a standard for cross-platform hard disk encryption. It provides secure management of multiple userpasswords and stores setup information in the partition header. LUKS for dm-crypt is now implemented in cryptsetup replacing the original cryptsetup. It provides all the functionally of the original version plus all LUKS features.  Homepage: https://gitlab.com/cryptsetup/cryptsetup

packages.name: cscope
packages.descl: Cscope is a text screen based source browsing tool. Although it is primarily designed to search C code (including lex and yacc files), it can also be used for C++ code.  Homepage: http://cscope.sourceforge.net

packages.name: cups
packages.descl: The Common UNIX Printing System provides a portable printing layer for UNIX(R)-like operating systems. It has been developed by Easy Software Products to promote a standard printing solution for all UNIX vendors and users. CUPS uses the Internet Printing Protocol ('IPP') as the basis for managing print jobs and queues. The CUPS package includes System V and Berkeley command-line interfaces, a PostScript RIP package for supporting non-PostScript printer drivers, and tools for creating additional printer drivers and other CUPS services.

packages.name: cups-filters
packages.descl: This package provides backends, filters, and other software that was once part of the core CUPS distribution but is no longer included. In addition it contains additional filters and software developed independently.

packages.name: curl
packages.descs: curl (command line URL data transfer tool)
packages.descl: Curl is a command line tool for transferring data specified with URL syntax. The command is designed to work without user interaction or any kind of interactivity. Curl offers a busload of useful tricks like proxy support, user authentication, ftp upload, HTTP post,  SSL (https:) connections, cookies, file transfer resume and more.  libcurl is a library that Curl uses to do its job. It is readily available to be used by your software, too.

packages.name: cvs
packages.descl: CVS is a version control system, which allows you to keep old versions of files (usually source code), keep a log of who, when, and why changes occurred, etc., like RCS or SCCS. It handles multiple developers, multiple directories, triggers to enable/log/control various operations, and can work over a wide area network.  Some of the people who have worked on CVS include: Dick Grune, Brian Berliner, Jeff Polk, and others too numerous to mention.

packages.name: cyrus-sasl
packages.descl: This is the Cyrus SASL library. Cyrus SASL is used by mail programs on the client or server side to provide authentication and authorization services. See RFC 2222 for more information.

packages.name: daemon
packages.descl: Daemon turns other processes into daemons. There are many tasks that need to be performed to correctly set up a daemon process. This can be tedious. Daemon performs these tasks for other processes. This is useful for writing daemons in languages other than C, C++ or Perl (e.g. `/bin/sh`, Java).  http://libslack.org/daemon/

packages.name: dash
packages.descl: DASH is a POSIX-compliant implementation of /bin/sh that aims to be as small as possible. It does this without sacrificing speed. In fact, it is significantly faster than bash (the GNU Bourne-Again SHell) for most tasks. DASH is a direct descendant of the NetBSD version of ash (Kenneth Almquist's Almquist shell), ported to Linux by Herbert Xu.  Homepage: http://gondor.apana.org.au/~herbert/dash Repository: http://git.kernel.org/?p=utils/dash/dash.git;a=summary

packages.name: db48
packages.descl: The Berkeley Database (Berkeley DB) library provides embedded database support for both traditional and client/server applications.  This package should be installed if compatibility is needed with databases created with the Berkeley DB version 4.8.x.

packages.name: dbus
packages.descl: D-Bus supplies both a system daemon (for events such as 'new hardware device added' or 'printer queue changed') and a per user login session daemon (for general IPC needs among user applications). Also, the message bus is built on top of a general one-to-one message passing framework, which can be used by any two apps to communicate directly (without going through the message bus daemon).  Homepage: https://dbus.freedesktop.org/

packages.name: dbus-glib
packages.descl: This package includes the glib bindings for the dbus IPC library.

packages.name: dbus-python
packages.descl: This package includes python bindings for the D-Bus messagebus.

packages.name: dc3dd
packages.descs: dc3dd (version of dd designed for computer forensics)
packages.descl: dc3dd is a patched version of GNU dd to include a number of features useful for computer forensics. Many of these features were inspired by dcfldd, but were rewritten for dc3dd. Added features include robust error handling, logging, progress meter, image verification, split output and more.  http://sourceforge.net/projects/dc3dd/

packages.name: dconf
packages.descl: dconf is a low-level configuration system. Its main purpose is to provide a backend to the GSettings API in GLib.  Homepage: http://live.gnome.org/dconf

packages.name: dconf-editor
packages.descl: The dconf-editor program provides a graphical interface for editing settings that are stored in the dconf database. The gsettings utility provides similar functionality on the command line.

packages.name: dcron
packages.descl: The cron daemon runs in the background and executes tasks on behalf of users at the appropriate time. Many timed system tasks are started with cron, such as the nightly indexing with updatedb.  dcron was written entirely from scratch by Matthew Dillon.

packages.name: ddd
packages.descl: GNU DDD is a graphical front-end for command-line debuggers such as GDB, DBX, WDB, Ladebug, JDB, XDB, the Perl debugger, the bash debugger, or the Python debugger. Besides 'usual' front-end features such as viewing source texts, DDD has become famous through its interactive graphical data display, where data structures are displayed as graphs.

packages.name: ddrescue
packages.descl: GNU ddrescue is a data recovery tool. It copies data from one file or block device (hard disc, cdrom, etc) to another, trying hard to rescue data in case of read errors. Every time you run it on the same output file, it tries to fill in the gaps.  ddrescue home: http://www.gnu.org/software/ddrescue/ddrescue.html

packages.name: dehydrated
packages.descl: This is a client for signing SSL certificates with an ACME server: Signing of a list of domains, including wildcard domains. Signing of a CSR, standalone or completely automated using hooks. Renewal if a cert is about to expire or included domains changed. Revoking certificates if you need to.  Homepage: https://dehydrated.io/

packages.name: dejavu-fonts-ttf
packages.descl: The DejaVu fonts are a font family based on the Bitstream Vera Fonts. Its purpose is to provide a wider range of characters while maintaining the original look and feel.  Homepage: http://dejavu-fonts.github.io

packages.name: desktop-file-utils
packages.descl: Some utilities from freedesktop.org for handling .desktop files:  desktop-file-validate: validates a desktop file and prints warnings/errors about spec violations. desktop-file-install: installs a desktop file to the applications directory, optionally munging it a bit in transit. desktop-menu-tool: loads .vfolder-info and .menu files and does operations on them.

packages.name: dev86
packages.descl: This is a complete 8086 assembler and loader which can make 32-bit code for the 386+ processors. In the past it was used to compile the 16-bit bootsector and setup binaries for the kernel, but modern (2.4.x or newer) kernels use GNU ld instead.  Homepage: http://v3.sk/~lkundrak/dev86/

packages.name: devs
packages.descl: This package creates special files in the /dev directory that represent your system's hardware, and a tool (/dev/MAKEDEV) for creating new device files.  These files are required to access hardware on a Linux system.

packages.name: dhcp
packages.descl: This package provides the ISC's DHCP utilities, including both a server and client. The DHCP protocol allows a host to contact a central server which maintains a list of IP addresses which may be assigned on one or more subnets.  A DHCP client may request an address from this pool, and then use it temporarily for communication on the network.  The DHCP protocol also provides a mechanism whereby a client can learn important details about the network to which it is attached, such as the location of a default router or name server.

packages.name: dhcpcd
packages.descl: The DHCP client program dhcpcd is used to connect to a network by contacting a DHCP server. dhcpcd gets an IP address and other information from a corresponding DHCP server, configures the network interface automatically, and tries to renew the lease time according to RFC2131 or RFC1541 depending on the command line option.  Homepage: https://roy.marples.name/projects/dhcpcd

packages.name: dialog
packages.descs: dialog (display dialog boxes from shell scripts)
packages.descl: Dialog is a program to present a variety of questions or display messages using dialog boxes from a shell script. The Slackware package management script 'pkgtool' uses this, as do various other menu-driven console scripts.  Dialog was originally contributed to Slackware by Savio Lam, and has been contributed to by many. Dialog is currently maintained by Thomas E. Dickey. Homepage: https://invisible-island.net/dialog/

packages.name: diffstat
packages.descl: DiffStat is a simple filter that reads the output of the 'diff' program and displays a histogram of insertions, deletions, and modifications per-file. It is useful for reviewing large, complex patch files.  Thomas E. Dickey is the author of DiffStat.

packages.name: diffutils
packages.descl: The GNU diff utilities finds differences between files. A major use for this package is to make source code patches.

packages.name: digikam
packages.descl: digiKam is a simple digital photo management application for KDE, which makes importing and organizing digital photos a snap. The photos can be organized in albums which can be sorted chronologically, by directory layout, or by custom collections. An easy to use interface enables you to connect to your camera and preview, download, and/or delete your images.  Homepage: http://www.digikam.org/

packages.name: distcc
packages.descl: distcc allows compilation of C code to be distributed across several machines on a network. distcc should always generate the same results as a local compile, is simple to install and use, and is often significantly faster than a local compile.  IMPORTANT SECURITY NOTE: distccd should only run on trusted networks.  distcc was written by Martin Pool.

packages.name: djvulibre
packages.descl: DjVu is a web-centric format and software platform for distributing documents and images. DjVu content downloads faster, displays and renders faster, looks nicer on a screen, and consume less client resources than competing formats. DjVu was originally developed at AT&T Labs-Research by Leon Bottou, Yann LeCun, Patrick Haffner, and many others.  Homepage: http://djvu.sourceforge.net

packages.name: dmapi
packages.descl: A library required to use the Data Management API (DMAPI). This interface is defined in the X/Open document 'Systems Management: Data Storage Management (XDSM) API' dated February 1997.  The DMAPI library is used by the xfsdump utility.

packages.name: dmidecode
packages.descl: dmidecode is a tool for dumping a computer's DMI table (some say SMBIOS) contents in a human-readable format. This table contains a description of the system's hardware components, as well as other useful pieces of information such as serial numbers and BIOS revision.  dmidecode was written by Alan Cox and Jean Delvare.

packages.name: dnsmasq
packages.descl: Dnsmasq is a lightweight, easy to configure DNS forwarder and DHCP server. It is designed to provide DNS (and optionally DHCP) to a small network, and can serve the names of local machines which are not in the global DNS.  Dnsmasq was written by Simon Kelley.  Homepage: http://www.thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/

packages.name: dolphin
packages.descl: Dolphin is a lightweight file manager. It has been designed with ease of use and simplicity in mind, while still allowing flexibility and customization.  Homepage: https://www.kde.org/applications/system/dolphin/

packages.name: dolphin-plugins
packages.descl: This package contains plugins that offer integration of various version control systems in Dolphin.

packages.name: dosfstools
packages.descs: dosfstools (tools for working with FAT filesystems)
packages.descl: Utilities for creating FAT filesystems (mkdosfs), and for checking and repairing them (dosfsck).  Homepage: http://daniel-baumann.ch/software/dosfstools

packages.name: dotconf
packages.descl: Dot.conf is a lightweight and simple configuration file parser that contains many features.  Homepage: https://github.com/williamh/dotconf/

packages.name: dovecot
packages.descl: Dovecot is an open source IMAP and POP3 server for Linux/UNIX-like systems, written with security foremost in mind.  Dovecot can work with standard mbox and Maildir formats and it is fully compatible with UW-IMAP and Courier IMAP servers' implementation of them, as well as mail clients accessing the mailboxes directly.

packages.name: doxygen
packages.descl: Doxygen is a documentation system for C++, C, Java, IDL, and to some extent PHP and C#. Doxygen generates project documentation using special documentation blocks in the source code, easing the process of keeping docs and code in sync. Doxygen produces documentation in several output formats, including HTML, LaTeX, man pages, RTF, XML, compressed HTML, PostScript, and PDF.  Homepage: https://www.doxygen.org

packages.name: dragon
packages.descl: Dragon Player is a multimedia player where the focus is on simplicity, instead of features. Dragon Player does one thing, and only one thing, which is playing multimedia files.

packages.name: drkonqi
packages.descl: Drkonqi is the crash handler for KDE Frameworks 5 / Plasma5.

packages.name: dvd+rw-tools
packages.descl: A collection of tools to master DVD+RW/+R/-R/-RW media. For further information see http://fy.chalmers.se/~appro/linux/DVD+RW/.  The DVD+RW tools were written by Andy Polyakov.

packages.name: dvdauthor
packages.descl: dvdauthor is a program that will generate a DVD movie from a valid MPEG2 stream. The resulting movie should play in a standard DVD player.  Homepage: http://dvdauthor.sf.net

packages.name: e2fsprogs
packages.descl: Utilities needed to create and maintain ext2, ext3, and ext4 filesystems.  These utilities were written by Remy Card (the developer and maintainer of the ext2 fs) and Theodore T'so.  https://kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/people/tytso/e2fsprogs

packages.name: easytag
packages.descl: EasyTAG is a utility for viewing and editing tags for MP3, MP2, FLAC, Ogg Vorbis, Speex and Opus, MP4/AAC, MusePack, Monkey's Audio and WavPack files. Its simple and nice GTK+ interface makes tagging easy.  Homepage: http://easytag.sourceforge.net

packages.name: ebook-tools
packages.descs: ebook-tools (access and convert various ebook file formats)
packages.descl: Tools for accessing and converting various ebook file formats.  Home page: http://sourceforge.net/projects/ebook-tools/

packages.name: ebtables
packages.descs: ebtables (Ethernet frame filtering on a Linux bridge)
packages.descl: The ebtables utility enables basic Ethernet frame filtering on a Linux bridge, logging, MAC NAT and brouting. It only provides basic IP filtering, the full-fledged IP filtering on a Linux bridge is done with iptables.  Homepage: https://ebtables.netfilter.org

packages.name: ed
packages.descl: GNU ed is an 8-bit clean, more or less POSIX-compliant implementation of the standard Unix line editor. These days, full-screen editors have rendered 'ed' mostly of historical interest. Nonetheless, it appeals to a handful of aging programmers who still believe that 'Small is Beautiful'.

packages.name: editorconfig-core-c
packages.descl: EditorConfig makes it easy to maintain the correct coding style when switching between different text editors and between different projects. The EditorConfig project maintains a file format and plugins for various text editors which allow this file format to be read and used by those editors. For information on the file format and supported text editors, see the EditorConfig website.  Homepage: https://editorconfig.org

packages.name: editres
packages.descl: editres is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: efibootmgr
packages.descs: efibootmgr (tool to modify UEFI boot entries)
packages.descl: efibootmgr is a Linux userspace application to modify the Intel Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) Boot Manager. This application can create and destroy boot entries, change the boot order, change the next running boot option, and more.  Homepage: https://github.com/rhboot/efibootmgr

packages.name: efivar
packages.descs: efivar (library and utilities to handle UEFI variables)
packages.descl: The efivar package contains a library and utilities for manipulating UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) variables.  Homepage: https://github.com/rhboot/efivar

packages.name: egl-wayland
packages.descl: Wayland EGL External Platform library.

packages.name: eglexternalplatform
packages.descl: The header files for EGL External Platform Interface.

packages.name: eigen3
packages.descl: Eigen is a C++ template library for linear algebra: matrices, vectors, numerical solvers, and related algorithms.  Homepage: http://eigen.tuxfamily.org

packages.name: electricsheep
packages.descl: Electric Sheep is an xscreensaver module that displays mpeg video of an animated fractal flame. In the background it contributes render cycles to the next animation. Periodically it uploades completed frames to the server, where they are compressed for distribution to all clients. This program is recommended only if you have a high bandwidth connection to the internet such as DSL or cable modem.  electricsheep home: http://electricsheep.org/

packages.name: elementary-xfce
packages.descl: Elementary icons forked, extended, and maintained for Xfce.  Homepage: https://github.com/shimmerproject/elementary-xfce

packages.name: elfutils
packages.descs: elfutils (ELF object file access library and utilities)
packages.descl: Elfutils is a collection of utilities, including stack (to show backtraces), nm (for listing symbols from object files), size (for listing the section sizes of an object or archive file), strip (for discarding symbols), readelf (to see the raw ELF file structures), and elflint (to check for well-formed ELF files).  Homepage: ftp://sourceware.org/pub/elfutils/

packages.name: elilo
packages.descl: This is elilo, a boot loader originally developed by HP for IA-64 systems. This is used to load the kernel and initial ramdisk on machines that use UEFI. Since most UEFI implementations are 64-bit, the 64-bit EFI binary is generally the one to use (even for loading a 32-bit kernel).  Homepage: http://elilo.sourceforge.net

packages.name: elisa
packages.descl: Elisa is a simple music player that should be easy to use. It does not require any configuration before one can use it.  Homepage: https://community.kde.org/Elisa

packages.name: elm
packages.descl: Elm is an interactive screen-oriented mailer program originally written by Dave Taylor, and continued by the Elm Development Group.

packages.name: elogind
packages.descl: elogind is the systemd project's logind, extracted to a standalone package.  Homepage: https://github.com/elogind/elogind

packages.name: elvis
packages.descl: Elvis is a text editor. It is intended to be a modern replacement for the classic ex/vi editor of UNIX fame. Elvis supports many new features, including multiple edit buffers, multiple windows, and a variety of display modes.  Please note that elvis does not support UTF8.

packages.name: emacs
packages.descl: Emacs is the extensible, customizable, self-documenting real-time display editor. If this seems to be a bit of a mouthful, an easier explanation is that Emacs is a text editor and more. At its core is an interpreter for Emacs Lisp, a dialect of the Lisp programming language with extensions to support text editing. This version supports X.  Homepage: http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/

packages.name: emacspeak
packages.descl: Emacspeak is a speech interface that allows visually impaired users to interact independently and efficiently with the computer. By seamlessly blending all aspects of the Internet such as Web-surfing and messaging, Emacspeak speech-enables local and remote information via a consistent and well-integrated user interface. Emacspeak has dramatically changed how the author, T. V. Raman, and hundreds of blind and visually impaired users around the world interact with the personal computer and the Internet.

packages.name: enchant
packages.descl: Enchant supports: * Aspell/Pspell * Ispell * MySpell/HunSpell * Uspell (Yiddish, Hebrew and Eastern European languages) * Hspell (Hebrew) and others  Homepage: https://abiword.github.io/enchant/

packages.name: encodings
packages.descl: encodings is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: enscript
packages.descs: enscript (converts text files to PostScript and other formats)
packages.descl: Enscript converts text files to PostScript and spools the generated output to a printer or saves it to a file. If no input files are given, enscript processes standard input. Enscript can be extended to handle different output media and it has many options for customizing printouts.

packages.name: epic5
packages.descl: EPIC is the (E)nhanced (P)rogrammable (I)RC-II (C)lient.  The EPIC home page is:       http://www.epicsol.org/ The EPIC main ftp site is:   ftp://ftp.epicsol.org/ The EPIC IRC channel is:     #epic on EFNet

packages.name: esound
packages.descl: EsounD, the Enlightened Sound Daemon, is a server process that mixes several audio streams for playback by a single audio device. For example, if you're listening to music on a CD and you receive a sound-related event from ICQ, the two applications won't have to jockey for the use of your sound card. Install esound if you'd like to let sound applications share your audio device.

packages.name: espeak-ng
packages.descl: The eSpeak NG (Next Generation) Text-to-Speech program is an open source speech synthesizer that supports many languages and accents. It is based on the eSpeak engine created by Jonathan Duddington. It uses spectral formant synthesis by default which sounds robotic, but can be configured to use Klatt formant synthesis or MBROLA to give it a more natural sound.  Homepage: https://github.com/espeak-ng/espeak-ng

packages.name: etc
packages.descl: System configuration files. The /etc directory is traditionally the location where configuration files are found.

packages.name: ethtool
packages.descs: ethtool (a tool for examining and tuning a network interface)
packages.descl: ethtool is a small utility for examining and tuning your Ethernet based network interface. For more details, see 'man ethtool'.  ethtool was written by David Miller, with help from Jakub Jelinek, Jeff Garzik, Tim Hockin, Eli Kupermann, Chris Leech, Scott Feldman, and Andi Kleen.

packages.name: eudev
packages.descl: eudev provides a dynamic device directory containing only the files for the devices which are actually present. It creates or removes device node files usually located in the /dev directory. eudev is a fork of git://anongit.freedesktop.org/systemd/systemd with the aim of isolating udev from any particular flavor of system initialization.  Homepage: https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Project:Eudev

packages.name: eventviews
packages.descl: KDE PIM library for creating events.

packages.name: exfatprogs
packages.descl: The exfatprogs package contains all of the standard utilities for creating, fixing, and debugging exFAT filesystems. The goal of exfatprogs is to provide high performance and quality at the level of exFAT exfat utilities in windows.  Homepage: https://github.com/exfatprogs/exfatprogs

packages.name: exiv2
packages.descs: exiv2 (Exif and IPTC Metadata Library and Tools)
packages.descl: Exiv2 is a C++ library and a command line utility to read and write Exif and IPTC image metadata.  Homepage: https://www.exiv2.org/

packages.name: exo
packages.descl: This is libexo, an extension library to Xfce, developed by os-cillation. While Xfce comes with quite a few libraries that are targeted at desktop development, libexo is targeted at application development. It also has some helper applications that are used throughout the entire desktop.

packages.name: expat
packages.descl: This is Expat, a C library for parsing XML, written by James Clark. Expat is a stream-oriented XML parser used by Python, GNOME, Xft2, and other things.  Homepage: https://libexpat.github.io

packages.name: expect
packages.descs: expect (program that talks to other interactive programs)
packages.descl: Expect is a program that talks to other interactive programs according to a script. Following the script, Expect knows what can be expected from a program and what the correct response should be. An interpreted language provides branching and high-level control structures to direct the dialogue.  Expect was written by Don Libes of the National Institute of Standards and Technology. Homepage: http://core.tcl.tk/expect

packages.name: extra-cmake-modules
packages.descl: This package contains additional CMake modules required for compiling KDE Frameworks 5.

packages.name: f2fs-tools
packages.descl: F2FS is a new file system designed for NAND flash memory-based storage devices. It uses a log structure file system approach adapted for this type of storage, and supports various parameters not only for configuring on-disk layout, but also for selecting allocation and cleaning algorithms.  Homepage: https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/jaegeuk/f2fs-tools.git

packages.name: falkon
packages.descl: Falkon is a QtWebEngine based cross-platform web browser.

packages.name: farstream
packages.descl: Farstream is a collection of GStreamer modules and libraries for videoconferencing.  Homepage: https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/Farstream

packages.name: fcitx
packages.descl: Fcitx is an input method framework with extension support. Currently it supports Linux and Unix systems like freebsd. It has three built- in Input Method Engine, Pinyin, QuWei and Table-based input methods. Fcitx tries to provide a native feeling under all desktop as well as a light weight core. You can easily customize it to fit your requirements.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-anthy
packages.descl: Anthy Wrapper for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-configtool
packages.descs: fcitx-configtool (GTK based config tool for Fcitx)
packages.descl: fcitx-configtool is a GTK3 based configuration tool for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-hangul
packages.descl: Hangul Wrapper for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-kkc
packages.descs: fcitx-kkc (Japanese Kana Kanji Engine for Fcitx)
packages.descl: Fcitx-kkc is a Kana Kanji engine for Fcitx. It provides Japanese input method using libkkc.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-libpinyin
packages.descl: libpinyin wrapper for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-m17n
packages.descs: fcitx-m17n (m17n input method engine wrapper for fcitx)
packages.descl: Fcitx wrapper for the m17n input method engine.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-qt5
packages.descl: Qt5 IM Module for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-sayura
packages.descl: Fcitx-Sayura is a Sinhala input method for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-table-extra
packages.descl: fcitx-table-extra provides extra tables for Fcitx, including Boshiamy, Zhengma, Cangjie, and Quick.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-table-other
packages.descl: fcitx-table-other provides some other tables for Fcitx, forked from ibus-table-others and scim-tables.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fcitx-unikey
packages.descl: Unikey (Vietnamese Input Method) engine support for Fcitx.  Homepage: https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Fcitx

packages.name: fetchmail
packages.descl: fetchmail is a mail retrieval and forwarding utility. It fetches mail from a POP, IMAP, or ETRN-capable remote mailserver and forwards it to your local (client) machine's delivery system. You can then handle the retrieved mail using normal mail user agents such as elm, pine, or mutt. The fetchmail utility can be run in a daemon mode to repeatedly poll one or more systems at a specified interval.  fetchmail is probably not secure.

packages.name: ffmpeg
packages.descs: ffmpeg (software to record, convert and stream audio and video)
packages.descl: FFmpeg is the leading multimedia framework, able to decode, encode, transcode, mux, demux, stream, filter and play pretty much anything that humans and machines have created. It supports the most obscure ancient formats up to the cutting edge. It includes libavcodec, the leading audio/video codec library.  Homepage: https://ffmpeg.org/

packages.name: ffmpegthumbnailer
packages.descl: FFmpegthumbnailer is a lightweight video thumbnailer that can be used by file managers to create thumbnails for your video files. The thumbnailer uses ffmpeg to decode frames from the video files, so supported videoformats depend on the configuration flags of ffmpeg.  Homepage: https://github.com/dirkvdb/ffmpegthumbnailer

packages.name: ffmpegthumbs
packages.descl: FFMpegThumbs is a video thumbnail generator for KDE file managers like Dolphin and Konqueror. It enables them to show preview images of video files using FFMpeg.

packages.name: fftw
packages.descs: fftw (Fastest Fourier Transform in the West)
packages.descl: FFTW is a free collection of fast C routines for computing the Discrete Fourier Transform in one or more dimensions. It includes complex, real, symmetric, and parallel transforms, and can handle arbitrary array sizes efficiently. FFTW is typically faster than other publicly-available FFT implementations, and is even competitive with vendor-tuned libraries.  Homepage: http://www.fftw.org/

packages.name: fig2dev
packages.descl: This package contains the binaries to transform .fig files (created by xfig) to some other formats like epsf and LaTeX. If you have installed xfig, you should also install this package if you want to use xfig to create other files than .fig files, which can then be included in your LaTeX documents.  Homepage: https://sourceforge.net/projects/mcj/files/

packages.name: file
packages.descs: file (a utility to determine file type)
packages.descl: This is Ian F. Darwin's 'file' utility, used to identify files. Christos Zoulas has been file's maintainer since 1994.  Home FTP site: ftp://ftp.astron.com/pub/file/

packages.name: filelight
packages.descl: Filelight allows you to quickly understand exactly where your diskspace is being used by graphically representing your file system.  Homepage: http://utils.kde.org/projects/filelight

packages.name: findutils
packages.descl: This package contains the GNU find and xargs programs. The find and xargs implementations comply with POSIX 1003.2. They also support some additional options, some borrowed from Unix and some unique to GNU.

packages.name: flac
packages.descl: FLAC stands for Free Lossless Audio Codec. Grossly oversimplified, FLAC is similar to MP3, but lossless. 'Free' means that the specification of the stream format is in the public domain, and that neither the FLAC format nor any of the implemented encoding/decoding methods are covered by any patent. It also means that the sources for libFLAC and libFLAC++ are available under the LGPL and the sources for flac, metaflac, and the plugins are available under the GPL.  FLAC was developed by Josh Coalson.

packages.name: flex
packages.descl: flex is a tool for generating programs that perform pattern matching on text. flex is a rewrite of the AT&T Unix lex tool (the two implementations do not share any code, though), with some extensions (and incompatibilities).  Homepage: https://github.com/westes/flex

packages.name: floppy
packages.descl: Contains fdutils, tools to test and format floppy disks; and mtools, a collection of utilities to access FAT disks without mounting them.

packages.name: fluidsynth
packages.descl: FluidSynth is a real-time software synthesizer based on the Soundfont 2 specifications. FluidSynth reads and handles MIDI events from the MIDI input device. It is the software analogue of a MIDI synthesizer. FluidSynth can also play midifiles using a Soundfont.  Homepage: http://www.fluidsynth.org/

packages.name: fluxbox
packages.descl: Fluxbox is yet another windowmanager for X that is based on blackbox but with many new features.

packages.descl: font-adobe-100dpi is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.descl: font-sony-misc is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.descl: font-winitzki-cyrillic is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: font-xfree86-type1
packages.descl: font-xfree86-type1 is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: fontconfig
packages.descl: Fontconfig is a library and tools designed to provide system-wide font configuration, customization, and application access.  Fontconfig is written and maintained by Keith Packard.  Homepage: https://www.fontconfig.org

packages.name: fonttosfnt
packages.descs: fonttosfnt (utility to wrap a bitmap font in a sfnt wrapper)
packages.descl: fonttosfnt is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: frameworkintegration
packages.descl: Framework providing components to allow applications to integrate with a KDE Workspace.  Homepage: https://community.kde.org/Frameworks

packages.name: freecell-solver
packages.descl: Freecell Solver is a program that automatically solves layouts of Freecell and similar variants of Card Solitaire such as Eight Off, Forecell, and Seahaven Towers, as well as Simple Simon boards.  Homepage: https://fc-solve.shlomifish.org/

packages.name: freeglut
packages.descl: freeglut is a completely OpenSourced alternative to the OpenGL Utility Toolkit (GLUT) library. GLUT (and hence freeglut) allows the user to create and manage windows containing OpenGL contexts on a wide range of platforms and also read the mouse, keyboard, and joystick functions.  Homepage: http://freeglut.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: freerdp
packages.descl: FreeRDP is a free implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP), released under the Apache license.  Homepage: https://www.freerdp.com

packages.name: freetype
packages.descs: freetype (A free, high-quality, and portable font engine)
packages.descl: FreeType is a free and portable font rendering engine. It has been developed to provide support for a number of font formats, including TrueType, Type 1, and OpenType, and is designed to be small, efficient, highly customizable, and portable while capable of producing high-quality output.  Homepage: http://www.freetype.org

packages.name: frei0r-plugins
packages.descl: Frei0r is a minimalistic plugin API for video effects. The main emphasis is on simplicity for an API that will round up the most common video effects into simple filters, sources, and mixers that can be controlled by parameters. Its goal is that these simple effects can be shared between many applications, avoiding their reimplementation by different projects.  Homepage: http://frei0r.dyne.org

packages.name: fribidi
packages.descl: This library implements the Unicode BiDirectional algorithm, which is needed in order to support right-to-left languages such as Arabic and Hebrew. It is used in display software like KDE's SVG modules.  Homepage: https://github.com/fribidi/fribidi

packages.name: fslsfonts
packages.descs: fslsfonts (produces a list of fonts served by an X font server)
