packages.descl: fslsfonts is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: fstobdf
packages.descs: fstobdf (copy fonts from an X11 font server)
packages.descl: The fstobdf program reads a font from a font server and prints a BDF file on the standard output that may be used to recreate the font. This is useful in testing servers, debugging font metrics, and reproducing lost BDF files.

packages.name: fuse
packages.descl: FUSE is a simple interface for userspace programs to export a virtual filesystem to the Linux kernel. FUSE also aims to provide a secure method for non privileged users to create and mount their own filesystem implementations.  Homepage: https://github.com/libfuse/libfuse

packages.name: fuse3
packages.descl: FUSE is a simple interface for userspace programs to export a virtual filesystem to the Linux kernel. FUSE also aims to provide a secure method for non privileged users to create and mount their own filesystem implementations.  Homepage: https://github.com/libfuse/libfuse

packages.name: fvwm
packages.descs: fvwm (a small and fast virtual window manager for X)
packages.descl: Fvwm is the classic highly-configurable virtual window manager for X11. It is a derivative of twm, redesigned to minimize memory consumption, provide a 3-D look to window frames, and provide a simple virtual desktop.  Homepage: http://www.fvwm.org Development: https://github.com/fvwmorg/fvwm

packages.name: gamin
packages.descl: Gamin is a file and directory monitoring system defined to be a subset of the FAM (File Alteration Monitor) system.  The homepage for Gamin is: http://www.gnome.org/~veillard/gamin/

packages.name: garcon
packages.descl: This is garcon, a freedesktop.org compliant menu implementation based on GLib and GIO. It was started as a rewrite of the former Xfce menu library called libxfce4menu.

packages.name: gawk
packages.descl: Gawk is the GNU Project's implementation of the AWK programming language. It conforms to the definition of the language in the POSIX 1003.2 Command Language And Utilities Standard. This version in turn is based on the description in The AWK Programming Language, by Aho, Kernighan, and Weinberger, with the additional features found in the System V Release 4 version of UNIX awk. Gawk also provides more recent Bell Labs awk extensions, and some GNU-specific extensions.

packages.name: gc
packages.descl: The Boehm-Demers-Weiser conservative garbage collector can be used as a garbage collecting replacement for C malloc or C++ new.  Homepage: http://www.hboehm.info/gc/

packages.name: gcc
packages.descs: gcc (Base GCC package with C support)
packages.descl: GCC is the GNU Compiler Collection.  This package contains those parts of the compiler collection needed to compile C code. Other packages add Ada, C++, D, Fortran, Go, Objective-C, and BRIG support to the compiler core.

packages.name: gcc-brig
packages.descl: BRIG support for the GNU Compiler Collection.  BRIG is the binary form of the Heterogeneous System Architecture Intermediate Language (HSA IL), which is a virtual instruction set for parallel programs. While similar in some ways to OpenCL or CUDA, HSA is designed to ease the burden on the programmer by automatically handling the offloading of tasks and moving of data.

packages.name: gcc-g++
packages.descl: C++ support for the GNU Compiler Collection.  This package contains those parts of the compiler collection needed to compile C++ code.

packages.name: gcc-gdc
packages.descl: D support for the GNU Compiler Collection.  D is a general-purpose programming language with static typing, systems-level access, and C-like syntax.

packages.name: gcc-gfortran
packages.descl: The GNU Fortran compiler is fully compliant with the Fortran 95 Standard and includes legacy F77 support. In addition, a significant number of Fortran 2003 and Fortran 2008 features are implemented. GNU Fortran also contains many standard and extensions and can be used to run real-world programs.  This package contains those parts of the compiler collection needed to compile Fortran code.

packages.name: gcc-gnat
packages.descl: Ada support for the GNU Compiler Collection.  This package contains those parts of the compiler collection needed to compile Ada code. GNAT implements Ada 95, Ada 2005 and Ada 2012, and it may also be invoked in Ada 83 compatibility mode. By default, GNAT assumes Ada 2012.

packages.name: gcc-go
packages.descl: Go is a compiled, garbage-collected, concurrent programming language developed by Google Inc. The initial design of Go was started in September 2007 by Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, and Ken Thompson. Rob Pike has stated that Go is being used 'for real stuff' at Google. Go's 'gc' compiler targets the Linux, Mac OS X, FreeBSD, OpenBSD and Microsoft Windows operating systems, and the i386, amd64, and ARM processor architectures.  Homepage: http://golang.org

packages.name: gcc-objc
packages.descl: Objective-C/C++ support for the GNU Compiler Collection.  This package contains those parts of the compiler collection needed to compile code written in Objective-C and Objective-C++. Objective-C was originally developed to add object-oriented extensions to the C language, and is best known as the native language of the NeXT computer.

packages.name: gccmakedep
packages.descl: gccmakedep is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: gcr
packages.descs: gcr (crypto library and ui for gnome-keyring)
packages.descl: GCR is a library for displaying certificates and crypto UI accessing key stores. It also provides the viewer for crypto files on the GNOME desktop.  GCK is a library for accessing PKCS#11 modules like smart cards, in a (G)object oriented way.

packages.name: gd
packages.descl: gd is a graphics library. It allows your code to quickly draw images complete with lines, arcs, text, multiple colors, cut and paste from other images, and flood fills, and write out the result as a PNG or JPEG file. This is particularly useful in web applications, where PNG and JPEG are two of the formats accepted for inline images by most browsers. The gd library was written by Thomas Boutell.  Homepage: https://www.libgd.org

packages.name: gdb
packages.descl: GDB, the GNU Project debugger, allows you to see what is going on inside another program while it executes - or what another program was doing at the moment it crashed. GDB can do four main kinds of things to help you catch bugs in the act: 1) Start your program, specifying anything that might affect its behavior. 2) Make your program stop on specified conditions. 3) Examine what has happened, when your program has stopped. 4) Change things in your program, so you can experiment with correcting the effects of one bug and go on to learn about another. The program being debugged can be written in Ada, C, C++, Objective-C, Pascal and many other languages.

packages.name: gdbm
packages.descl: GNU dbm is a set of database routines that work similar to the standard UNIX dbm routines.

packages.name: gdk-pixbuf2
packages.descs: gdk-pixbuf2 (image library used by GTK+ v2)
packages.descl: The gdk-pixbuf library provides a number of features: - GdkPixbuf structure for representing images. - Image loading facilities, both synchronous and progressive. - Rendering of a GdkPixbuf into various formats: drawables (windows, pixmaps), GdkRGB buffers. - Fast scaling and compositing of pixbufs. - Simple animation loading (ie. animated gifs).

packages.name: gdk-pixbuf2-xlib
packages.descl: GdkPixbuf-Xlib contains the deprecated API for integrating GdkPixbuf with Xlib data types. This library was originally shipped as part of the gdk-pixbuf2 package, and has since been moved out of the original repository.

packages.name: geeqie
packages.descl: Geeqie is an interactive GTK based image viewer that supports multiple image formats, zooming, panning, thumbnails, and sorting images into collections.  Homepage: http://www.geeqie.org

packages.name: gegl
packages.descl: GEGL (Generic Graphics Library) is a graph based image processing framework.  GEGL provides infrastructure to do demand based cached non destructive image editing on larger than RAM buffers. Through babl it provides support for a wide range of color models and pixel storage formats for input and output.

packages.name: genpower
packages.descl: The genpower daemon, genpowerd, will monitor the status of a serial line connected to a UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply). If a power failure is detected, genpowerd will notify the system to take the needed steps to react to the condition of the UPS. This may include shutting the system down, or canceling a pending shutdown if the power is restored.

packages.name: getmail
packages.descl: getmail is a POP3 mail retriever, with support for both ordinary and domain (or multidrop) POP3 mailboxes. It is written in Python, and licensed under the GNU General Public License version 2.  getmail was written by Charles Cazabon.

packages.name: gettext
packages.descl: The GNU gettext package contains 'gettext' and 'ngettext', programs that are used to internationalize the messages given by shell scripts.

packages.name: gettext-tools
packages.descl: The GNU gettext-tools package is useful for authors and maintainers of internationalized software, or for anyone compiling programs that use the gettext functions. This package provides the needed tools and library functions for the handling of messages in different languages. Some other GNU packages use the gettext program (included in this package) to internationalize the messages given by shell scripts.

packages.name: gexiv2
packages.descl: gexiv2 is a GObject-based wrapper around the Exiv2 library. It makes the basic features of Exiv2 available to GNOME applications.  Homepage: https://wiki.gnome.org/gexiv2

packages.name: gftp
packages.descl: gFTP is a multithreaded FTP client for X written using GTK+. It features simultaneous downloads, resuming of interrupted file transfers, file transfer queues, downloading of entire directories, ftp proxy support, remote directory caching, passive and non-passive file transfers, drag-n-drop support, bookmarks menu, stop button, and many more features.

packages.name: ghostscript
packages.descl: Ghostscript is an interpreter of Adobe Systems' PostScript(tm) and Portable Document Format (PDF) languages. Ghostscript is an essential part of the printing subsystem, taking PostScript output from applications and converting it into an appropriate printer or display format. Ghostscript supports many printers directly, and more are supported through add-on packages.

packages.name: ghostscript-fonts-std
packages.descl: These fonts are used by the GhostScript interpreter.

packages.name: giflib
packages.descl: A library to load and save (uncompressed only) images using GIF, or Graphics Interchange Format. GIF was introduced by CompuServe in 1987, but is still widely used today (especially on web pages.)

packages.name: gimp
packages.descl: The GIMP is a powerful tool for the preparation and manipulation of digital images. The GIMP provides the user with a wide variety of image manipulation, painting, processing, and rendering tools. The GIMP's open design and extensible architecture make for a very powerful end product for photo and image retouching, web graphics design, or digital illustration.

packages.name: git
packages.descl: Git is a fast, scalable, distributed revision control system with an unusually rich command set that provides both high-level operations and full access to internals.  'git' can mean anything, depending on your mood.  Git was originally written by Linus Torvalds and is currently maintained by Junio C. Hamano.

packages.name: gjs
packages.descl: Use the GNOME platform libraries in your JavaScript programs. GJS powers GNOME Shell, Polari, GNOME Documents, and many other apps. Under the hood it uses SpiderMonkey, Mozilla's JavaScript engine originally developed for Firefox.  Homepage: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/

packages.name: gkrellm
packages.descl: GKrellM charts SMP CPU, load, Disk, and all active net interfaces automatically. An on/off button and online timer for the PPP interface is provided. Monitors for memory and swap usage, file system, internet connections, APM laptop battery, mbox style mailboxes, and cpu temps. Also includes an uptime monitor, hostname label, and clock/calendar.  Bill Wilson is the author of GKrellM.

packages.name: glade
packages.descl: Glade is a RAD tool to enable quick and easy development of user interfaces for the GTK+ toolkit and the GNOME desktop environment. The user interfaces designed in Glade are saved as XML, and by using the GtkBuilder GTK+ object these can be loaded by applications dynamically as needed.  Homepage: http://glade.gnome.org/

packages.name: glew
packages.descl: The OpenGL Extension Wrangler Library (GLEW) is a cross-platform open-source C/C++ extension loading library. GLEW provides efficient run-time mechanisms for determining which OpenGL extensions are supported on the target platform.  Homepage: http://glew.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: glib
packages.descl: GLib is a library which includes support routines for C such as lists, trees, hashes, memory allocation, and many other things.  GLib is required by nearly everything that uses GTK+ version 1.x.

packages.name: glib-networking
packages.descl: This package contains network-related giomodules for glib.

packages.name: glib2
packages.descl: GLib is the low-level core library that forms the basis for projects such as GTK+ and GNOME. It provides data structure handling for C, portability wrappers, and interfaces for such runtime functionality as an event loop, threads, dynamic loading, and an object system.  Homepage: https://www.gtk.org

packages.name: glibc
packages.descl: This package contains the GNU C libraries and header files. You'll need this package to compile programs.  The GNU C library was originally authored by Roland McGrath.  Homepage: https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/

packages.name: glibc-i18n
packages.descl: These files go in /usr/lib/locale, /usr/share/i18n/, and /usr/share/locale/ to provide internationalization support. You'll need this package unless you will be using US English only.

packages.name: glibc-profile
packages.descs: glibc-profile (GNU C libraries with profiling support)
packages.descl: This package contains static versions of the GNU C libraries with support for profiling binaries using gprof. gprof calculates how much time a program spends in each routine which can suggest where to concentrate efforts to improve performance.  See the gprof man page for more details.

packages.name: glibc-zoneinfo
packages.descl: This package allows you to configure your time zone.  This timezone database comes from the tzdata and tzcode packages by Arthur David Olson et al. The latest version and more information may be found at: https://www.iana.org/time-zones  Use the timeconfig utility to set your local time zone.

packages.name: glibmm
packages.descl: glibmm is a set of C++ bindings for glib, including cross-platform APIs such as a std::string-like UTF8 string class, string utility methods, such as a text encoding converter API, file access, and threads.  Homepage: http://www.gtkmm.org/

packages.name: glu
packages.descl: glu is the Mesa OpenGL utility library (libGLU).

packages.name: gmime
packages.descl: GMime is a set of utilities for parsing and creating messages using the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension (MIME) as defined by many Internet RFCs.  Jeffrey Stedfast is the author of GMime.

packages.name: gmm
packages.descl: Gmm++ is a generic C++ template library for sparse, dense and skyline matrices. It is built as a set of generic algorithms (mult, add, copy, sub-matrices, dense and sparse solvers, etc.) for any interfaced vector type or matrix type. It can be viewed as a glue library that allows cooperation between several vector and matrix types. However, basic sparse, dense and skyline matrix/vector types are built in Gmm++, so it can be used as a standalone linear algebra library.

packages.name: gmp
packages.descl: GNU MP is a library for arbitrary precision arithmetic, operating on signed integers, rational numbers, and floating point numbers. It has a rich set of functions, and the functions have a regular interface.

packages.name: gnome-keyring
packages.descs: gnome-keyring (a tool to handle security credentials)
packages.descl: GNOME Keyring is a program designed to take care of the user's security credentials, such as user names and passwords, in an easy to access manner. The keyring is implemented as a daemon and uses the process name gnome-keyring-daemon.

packages.name: gnome-themes-extra
packages.descl: A set of default icons used by many GTK+ applications.

packages.name: gnu-efi
packages.descs: gnu-efi (EFI Development files for the GNU toolchain)
packages.descl: Develop EFI applications using the GNU toolchain and the EFI development environment.  Homepage: http://gnu-efi.sourceforge.net

packages.name: gnuchess
packages.descs: gnuchess (GPL licensed chess engines and graphical frontends)
packages.descl: This is a package of programs for playing chess. It includes the gnuchess and Sjeng chess engines, and the eboard and XBoard graphical interfaces to these engines.

packages.name: gnucobol
packages.descl: GNU Cobol is an open source COBOL compiler. GNU Cobol implements a substantial part of the COBOL 85, COBOL 2002, and COBOL 2014 standards, as well as many extensions of the existent COBOL compilers. GNU Cobol translates COBOL into C and compiles the translated code using the native C compiler. GNU Cobol was written by Roger While and Keisuke Nishida, with the invaluable assistance of many others.  Homepage: ftp://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/gnucobol

packages.name: gnupg
packages.descl: GnuPG is GNU's tool for secure communication and data storage. It can be used to encrypt data and to create digital signatures. It includes an advanced key management facility and is compliant with the proposed OpenPGP Internet standard as described in RFC2440.

packages.name: gnupg2
packages.descl: GnuPG is GNU's tool for secure communication and data storage. It can be used to encrypt data and to create digital signatures. It includes an advanced key management facility and is compliant with the proposed OpenPGP Internet standard as described in RFC2440 and the S/MIME standard as described by several RFCs.  GnuPG 2.x is the stable version of GnuPG integrating support for OpenPGP and S/MIME. It does not conflict with an installed 1.4.x OpenPGP-only version.

packages.name: gnuplot
packages.descl: Gnuplot is a command-line driven interactive function plotting utility for UNIX, MSDOS, and VMS platforms. The software is copyrighted but freely distributed (i.e., you don't have to pay for it). It was originally intended as graphical program which would allow scientists and students to visualize mathematical functions and data. Gnuplot supports many different types of terminals, plotters, and printers (including many color devices, and pseudo-devices like LaTeX) and is easily extensible to include new devices.

packages.name: gnutls
packages.descl: This is a TLS (Transport Layer Security) 1.0 and SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) 3.0 implementation. In brief, GnuTLS can be described as a library which offers an API to access secure communication protocols. These protocols provide privacy over insecure lines, and were designed to prevent eavesdropping, tampering, or message forgery.  Homepage: http://www.gnu.org/software/gnutls/

packages.name: gobject-introspection
packages.descl: GObject Introspection is a project for providing machine readable introspection data of the API of C libraries. This introspection data can be used for automatic code generation for bindings, API verification, and documentation generation.  For more information, check out: http://live.gnome.org/GObjectIntrospection

packages.name: gpa
packages.descl: GPA is a graphical frontend for the GNU Privacy Guard (GnuPG, http://www.gnupg.org). GPA can be used to encrypt, decrypt, and sign files, to verify signatures and to manage the private and public keys.

packages.name: gparted
packages.descl: With GParted you can resize, copy, and move partitions without data loss, enabling you to:  * Grow or shrink your C: drive * Create space for new operating systems * Attempt data rescue from lost partitions  http://gparted.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: gperf
packages.descl: gperf is a perfect hash function generator written in C++. It transforms an n element user-specified keyword set W into a perfect hash function F. gperf currently generates the reserved keyword recognizer for lexical analyzers in several production and research compilers and language processing tools, including GNU C, GNU C++, GNU Java, GNU Pascal, GNU Modula 3, and GNU indent.  gperf was written by by Douglas C. Schmidt and Bruno Haible.

packages.name: gpgme
packages.descl: GPGME (GnuPG Made Easy) is a C language library that allows to add support for cryptography to a program. It is designed to make access to public key crypto engines like GnuPG or GpgSM easier for applications. GPGME provides a high-level crypto API for encryption, decryption, signing, signature verification and key management.  GPGME uses GnuPG and GpgSM as its backends to support OpenPGP and the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS).

packages.name: gphoto2
packages.descl: libgphoto2 is a cross-platform digital camera library, and gphoto2 is a command-line client for it.  Homepage: http://www.gphoto.org

packages.name: gpm
packages.descl: The general purpose mouse server, or gpm, allows you to use the mouse to cut and paste text from the screen. It also acts as a mouse server for applications running on the Linux console, such as the Midnight Commander file manager.

packages.name: gptfdisk
packages.descl: GPT fdisk (consisting of the gdisk, cgdisk, sgdisk, and fixparts programs) is a set of text-mode partitioning tools for using a GPT (GUID Partition Table), rather than the traditional MBR (Master Boot Record) partition tables. It features several partitioning tools, recovery tools to help you deal with corrupt partition tables, and the ability to convert MBR disks to GPT format.  Homepage: http://sourceforge.net/projects/gptfdisk/

packages.name: granatier
packages.descl: Granatier is a clone of the classic Bomberman game, inspired by the work of the Clanbomber clone.

packages.name: grantlee
packages.descl: Grantlee is a plugin based String Template system written with the Qt framework. The goals of the project are to make it easier for application developers to separate the structure of documents from the data they contain, opening the door for theming.  Homepage: https://github.com/steveire/grantlee

packages.name: grantlee-editor
packages.descl: Editor for Grantlee themes.

packages.name: grantleetheme
packages.descl: grantleetheme is a library for Grantlee theming support.

packages.name: graphene
packages.descs: graphene (a thin layer of types for graphic libraries)
packages.descl: A thin layer of types needed to write a canvas library dealing with points, rectangles, affine matrices, 2D transformations, 4x4 matrices, projections, transformations, vectors, and quaternions. It does not deal with windowing system surfaces, drawing, scene graphs, or input, keeping things small and essential.  Homepage: https://ebassi.github.io/graphene/

packages.name: graphite2
packages.descl: Graphite is a system that can be used to create 'smart fonts' capable of displaying writing systems with various complex behaviors. A smart font contains not only letter shapes but also additional instructions indicating how to combine and position the letters in complex ways.  Homepage: http://graphite.sil.org/

packages.name: grep
packages.descl: This is GNU grep, the 'fastest grep in the west' (we hope). Grep searches through textual input for lines which contain a match to a specified pattern and then prints the matching lines.

packages.name: groff
packages.descl: The GNU groff package provides versions of troff, nroff, eqn, tbl, and other Unix text-formatting utilities. Groff is used to 'compile' man pages stored in groff/nroff format into a form which can be printed or displayed on the screen. These man pages are stored in compressed form in the /usr/man/man? directories.

packages.name: grub
packages.descl: GNU GRUB is a multiboot boot loader.  Website: http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/

packages.name: gsettings-desktop-schemas
packages.descl: gsettings-desktop-schemas contains a collection of GSettings schemas for settings shared by various components of a desktop.

packages.name: gsl
packages.descs: gsl (a numerical library for C and C++ programmers)
packages.descl: The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) is a collection of routines for numerical computing. The routines are written from scratch by the GSL team in ANSI C, and present a modern API for C programmers, while allowing wrappers to be written for very high-level languages.  Homepage: http://www.gnu.org/software/gsl/

packages.name: gst-plugins-bad-free
packages.descl: GStreamer Bad Plug-ins is a set of plug-ins that aren't tested well enough, or the code is not of good enough quality. They might be close to being good quality, but they're missing something - be it a good code review, some documentation, a set of tests, a real live maintainer, or some actual wide use.  gst-plugins-bad-free packages the bad plugins with licenses that are free enough to ship.

packages.name: gst-plugins-base
packages.descl: GStreamer Base Plug-ins is a well-groomed and well-maintained collection of GStreamer plug-ins and elements, spanning the range of possible types of elements one would want to write for GStreamer. It also contains helper libraries and base classes useful for writing elements. A wide range of video and audio decoders, encoders, and filters are included.

packages.name: gst-plugins-good
packages.descl: GStreamer Good Plug-ins is a set of plug-ins that have good quality code, correct functionality, and a good license (LGPL for the plug-in code, LGPL or LGPL-compatible for the supporting library).

packages.name: gst-plugins-libav
packages.descl: GStreamer Libav plugin contains one plugin with a set of elements using the FFmpeg/Libav library code. It contains many popular decoders and encoders.  Home: http://gstreamer.freedesktop.org/modules/gst-libav.html

packages.name: gstreamer
packages.descl: GStreamer is a library that allows the construction of graphs of a media-handling components, ranging from simple Ogg/Vorbis playback to complex audio (mixing) and video (non-linear editing) processing. Applications can take advantage of advances in codec and filter technology transparently. Developers can add new codecs and filters by writing a simple plugin with a clean, generic interface.  GStreamer is released under the LGPL.

packages.name: gtk+
packages.descl: GTK+, which stands for the Gimp ToolKit, is a library for creating graphical user interfaces for the X Window System.  This library has been largely replaced by GTK+ version 2, but there are still some good programs that require it.

packages.name: gtk+2
packages.descl: This is GTK+, a multi-platform toolkit for creating graphical user interfaces. Offering a complete set of widgets, GTK+ is suitable for projects ranging from small one-off projects to complete application suites.

packages.name: gtk+3
packages.descl: This is GTK+, a multi-platform toolkit for creating graphical user interfaces. Offering a complete set of widgets, GTK+ is suitable for projects ranging from small one-off projects to complete application suites.

packages.name: gtk4
packages.descl: This is GTK, a multi-platform toolkit for creating graphical user interfaces. Offering a complete set of widgets, GTK+ is suitable for projects ranging from small one-off projects to complete application suites.

packages.name: gtkmm2
packages.descl: gtkmm is the official C++ interface for the popular GUI library GTK+. Highlights include typesafe callbacks, and a comprehensive set of widgets that are easily extensible via inheritance.  Homepage: http://www.gtkmm.org/

packages.name: gtkmm3
packages.descl: gtkmm is the official C++ interface for the popular GUI library GTK+. Highlights include typesafe callbacks, and a comprehensive set of widgets that are easily extensible via inheritance.  Homepage: http://www.gtkmm.org/

packages.name: gtksourceview3
packages.descs: gtksourceview3 (a GTK+ framework for source code editing)
packages.descl: GtkSourceView is a portable C library that extends the standard GTK+ framework for multiline text editing with support for configurable syntax highlighting, unlimited undo/redo, UTF-8 compliant caseless searching, printing and other features typical of a source code editor.  Homepage: https://projects.gnome.org/gtksourceview/

packages.name: gtkspell
packages.descl: GtkSpell provides MSWord/MacOSX-style highlighting of misspelled words in a GtkTextView widget. Right-clicking a misspelled word pops up a menu of suggested replacements.  Homepage: http://gtkspell.sourceforge.net

packages.name: gucharmap
packages.descl: gucharmap is a Unicode character map and font viewer.

packages.name: guile
packages.descl: This is Guile, Project GNU's extension language library. Guile is an interpreter for Scheme, packaged as a library that you can link into your applications to give them their own scripting language. Guile will eventually support other languages as well, giving users of Guile-based applications a choice of languages.

packages.name: gutenprint
packages.descs: gutenprint (IJS printer driver for Ghostscript and CUPS)
packages.descl: Gutenprint (formerly named Gimp-Print) is a suite of printer drivers that may be used with most common print spooling systems, including CUPS, LPRng, or others. These drivers provide high quality printing in many cases equal to or better than proprietary vendor-supplied drivers. Gutenprint also includes an enhanced print plug-in for the GIMP image editor.  Homepage: http://gimp-print.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: gv
packages.descl: gv is a PostScript and PDF previewer. It allows users to view and navigate through PostScript and PDF documents on an X display by providing a user interface for the ghostscript interpreter.  gv was written by Johannes Plass, using the source code for Tim Theisen's ghostview 1.5 as a starting point.

packages.name: gvfs
packages.descl: gvfs is a userspace virtual filesystem designed to work with the I/O abstractions of libgio (a library included in the glib2 package). It installs several modules that are automatically used by applications that use the libgio API. There is also fuse support that allows applications not using gio to access the gvfs filesystems.

packages.name: gwenview
packages.descl: Gwenview is a simple image viewer for KDE. It features a folder tree window and a file list window, providing easy navigation of your file hierarchy.

packages.name: gyp
packages.descl: GYP is a Meta-Build system: a build system that generates other build systems. GYP is intended to support large projects that need to be built on multiple platforms (e.g., Mac, Windows, Linux), and where it is important that the project can be built using the IDEs that are popular on each platform as if the project is a 'native' one.  Homepage: https://gyp.gsrc.io/

packages.name: gzip
packages.descl: Gzip reduces the size of the named files using Lempel-Ziv coding (LZ77). Whenever possible, each file is replaced by one with the extension .gz, while keeping the same ownership modes, access and modification times.

packages.name: hack-fonts-ttf
packages.descl: Hack is a typeface designed for writing source code. It expands upon the contributions of the Bitstream Vera and DejaVu projects. Hack includes monospaced regular, bold, oblique, and bold oblique sets to cover all of your syntax highlighting needs.  Homepage: http://sourcefoundry.org/hack/

packages.name: harfbuzz
packages.descl: HarfBuzz is an OpenType text shaping engine.  Homepage: http://harfbuzz.org

packages.name: haveged
packages.descl: The haveged project is an attempt to provide an easy-to-use, unpredictable random number generator based upon an adaptation of the HAVEGE algorithm. Haveged was created to remedy low-entropy conditions in the Linux random device that can occur under some workloads, especially on headless servers.  Homepage: http://www.issihosts.com/haveged/index.html

packages.name: hdparm
packages.descl: hdparm provides a command line interface to various hard disk ioctls supported by the Linux ATA/IDE device driver subsystem. This may be required to enable higher-performing disk modes.  hdparm was written by Mark Lord.  Homepage: https://sourceforge.net/projects/hdparm/

packages.name: help2man
packages.descl: help2man is a tool for automatically generating simple manual pages from program output.  Homepage: http://www.gnu.org/software/help2man

packages.name: hexchat
packages.descl: HexChat is an IRC client for Windows and UNIX-like operating systems.  Website: https://hexchat.github.io/

packages.name: hfsutils
packages.descl: hfsutils is a collection of tools for reading and writing Macintosh HFS volumes. These utilities can manipulate HFS volumes on nearly any medium. Since hfs and xhfs are linked with Tcl/Tk shared libraries, the hfsutils package is included here in the TCL software series.  hfsutils was written by Robert Leslie <rob@mars.org>

packages.name: hicolor-icon-theme
packages.descl: This is the default fallback theme used by implementations of the icon theme specification.  The specification is available at: http://www.freedesktop.org/standards/icon-theme-spec/  Homepage: https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/icon-theme

packages.name: hostname
packages.descl: The hostname utility is used to set or read the system hostname, domainname, dnsdomainname, nisdomainname, or ypdomainname. This package is required unless you want all of these set to (null), which you don't.  The hostname utility was written by Peter Tobias, Bernd Eckenfels, and Michael Meskes.

packages.name: hplip
packages.descl: HPLIP is an HP developed solution for printing, scanning, and faxing with HP inkjet and laser based printers in Linux. The HPLIP project provides printing support for more than 1400 HP printer models, including Deskjet, Officejet, Photosmart, PSC (Print Scan Copy), Business Inkjet, LaserJet, and LaserJet MFP.  Homepage: http://hplipopensource.com

packages.name: htdig
packages.descl: The ht://Dig system is a complete web indexing and searching system for a small domain or intranet. This system is not intended to replace the need for outside Internet search engines such as Google, but rather to cover the search needs for a single company, campus, or even a particular sub section of a web site.

packages.name: htop
packages.descl: htop is a free (GPL) ncurses-based process viewer that is similar to the well-known 'top' program, but allows to scroll the list vertically and horizontally to see all processes and their full command lines. Tasks related to processes (killing, renicing) can be done without entering their PIDs.  htop is developed by Hisham Muhammad. Homepage: http://hisham.hm/htop/

packages.name: httpd
packages.descl: Apache is an HTTP server designed as a plug-in replacement for the NCSA HTTP server. It fixes numerous bugs in the NCSA server and includes many frequently requested new features, and has an API which allows it to be extended to meet users' needs more easily.  Apache is the most popular web server in the known universe; over half of the servers on the Internet are running Apache or one of its variants.

packages.name: hunspell
packages.descs: hunspell (spell checker and morphological analyzer library)
packages.descl: Hunspell is a spell checker and morphological analyzer library and program designed for languages with rich morphology and complex word compounding or character encoding. Hunspell interfaces: Ispell-like terminal interface using ncurses library, Ispell pipe interface, and OpenOffice.org UNO module.  Homepage: http://hunspell.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: hwdata
packages.descl: hwdata contains various hardware identification and configuration data, such as the pci.ids database and MonitorsDB databases.  Homepage: https://github.com/vcrhonek/hwdata

packages.name: hyphen
packages.descl: Hyphen is a library for high quality hyphenation and justification.  Homepage: https://travis-ci.org/hunspell/hyphen

packages.name: ibus
packages.descl: IBus is an Intelligent Input Bus. It is a new input framework for Linux. It provides a full featured and user friendly input method user interface.  Homepage: https://github.com/ibus/ibus/wiki

packages.name: ibus-anthy
packages.descl: Japanese input engine for IBus.  Homepage: https://github.com/ibus/ibus-anthy

packages.name: ibus-hangul
packages.descs: ibus-hangul (Korean input method engine for IBus)
packages.descl: Korean input method engine for IBus.  Homepage: https://github.com/choehwanjin/ibus-hangul

packages.name: ibus-kkc
packages.descs: ibus-kkc (Japanese Kana Kanji Input for IBus)
packages.descl: A Japanese Kana Kanji Input Method Engine for IBus.  Homepage: https://github.com/ueno/ibus-kkc

packages.name: ibus-libpinyin
packages.descs: ibus-libpinyin (Pinyin engine based on libpinyin for IBus)
packages.descl: A Chinese Pinyin input method and a Chinese ZhuYin (Bopomofo) input method based on libpinyin for IBus.  Homepage: https://github.com/libpinyin/ibus-libpinyin

packages.name: ibus-m17n
packages.descl: M17N engine for IBus.  Homepage: https://github.com/ibus/ibus-m17n

packages.name: ibus-table
packages.descl: Ibus-table is a framework for table based input methods using IBus.  Ibus-table is mostly used for Chinese, table based input methods like ZhengMa, WuBi, ErBi, CangJie and so on.  Homepage: https://github.com/kaio/ibus-table

packages.name: ibus-unikey
packages.descs: ibus-unikey (Vietnamese input method engine for IBus)
packages.descl: Vietnamese input method engine for IBus.  Homepage: https://github.com/mrlequoctuan/ibus-unikey

packages.name: iceauth
packages.descl: The iceauth program is used to edit and display the authorization information used in connecting with ICE. It operates very much like the xauth program for X11 connection authentication records.

packages.name: icecream
packages.descl: Icecream is a distributed compile system. Icecream was created by SUSE based on distcc. Like distcc, Icecream takes compile jobs from a build and distributes it among remote machines allowing a parallel build. But unlike distcc, Icecream uses a central server that dynamically schedules the compile jobs to the fastest free server.  Homepage: https://github.com/icecc/icecream

packages.name: icmpinfo
packages.descl: Icmpinfo is a tool for looking at the ICMP messages received on the running host. It can be used to detect and record attack attempts, as well as help diagnose network problems.  icmpinfo was written by Laurent Demailly.

packages.name: ico
packages.descl: ico is a simple animation program that may be used for testing various X11 operations and extensions. It displays a wire-frame rotating polyhedron, with hidden lines removed, or a solid-fill polyhedron with hidden faces removed.

packages.name: icon-naming-utils
packages.descs: icon-naming-utils (generate icon files for your DE)
packages.descl: It is a script for maintaining backwards compatibility with current desktop icon themes, while migrating to the names specified in the Icon Naming Specification.  Homepage: http://tango.freedesktop.org

packages.name: icu4c
packages.descl: The International Components for Unicode (ICU) libraries provide robust and full-featured Unicode services on a wide variety of platforms.  Homepage: http://www.icu-project.org/

packages.name: id3lib
packages.descl: This package provides a library for manipulating ID3v1 and ID3v2 tags. Features include identification of valid tags, automatic size conversions, (re)synchronisation of tag frames, seamless tag (de)compression, and optional padding facilities. Additionally, it can display mp3 header info such as bitrate.  Homepage: http://id3lib.sourceforge.net/

packages.name: iftop
packages.descs: iftop (Display bandwidth usage on an interface)
packages.descl: iftop does for network usage what top(1) does for CPU usage. It listens to network traffic on a named interface and displays a table of current bandwidth usage by pairs of hosts. Handy for answering the question 'why is our link so slow?'.  Homepage: http://www.ex-parrot.com/~pdw/iftop/

packages.name: igt-gpu-tools
packages.descl: IGT GPU Tools is a collection of DRM driver tools that includes low- level tools and tests specifically for development and testing of DRM drivers.  Homepage: https://cgit.freedesktop.org/drm/igt-gpu-tools

packages.name: imagemagick
packages.descs: imagemagick (a robust collection of image processing tools)
packages.descl: ImageMagick is a collection of tools for manipulating and displaying digital images. It can merge images, transform image dimensions, do screen captures, create animation sequences, and convert between many different image formats.  ImageMagick was written by John Cristy of ImageMagick Studio.  Home page: http://www.imagemagick.org/

packages.name: imake
packages.descs: imake (C preprocessor interface to the make utility)
packages.descl: The imake package contains the imake utility, plus the following support programs: ccmakedep, mergelib, revpath, mkdirhier, makeg, cleanlinks, mkhtmlindex, and xmkmf.

packages.name: incidenceeditor
packages.descl: KDE PIM incidence editor for korganizer.

packages.name: indent
packages.descs: indent (changes the appearance of a C program)
packages.descl: GNU indent changes the appearance of a C program by inserting or deleting whitespace according to a plethora of options. Some canned styles of formatting (like the GNU style, Kernighan & Ritchie style, and original Berkeley style) are supported as well.  GNU indent is a descendant of BSD indent.

packages.name: inetd
packages.descl: This is a program to listen for connections on certain Internet sockets and invokes a program to service the request. Essentially, inetd allows running one daemon to invoke several others, reducing load on the system. Many of the network services are run through inetd, so you'll probably need it.  This version of inetd was ported from OpenBSD.

packages.name: infozip
packages.descl: zip is a compression and file packaging utility for Unix, VMS, MSDOS, OS/2, Windows NT, Minix, Atari and Macintosh, Amiga and Acorn RISC OS. It is analogous to a combination of the UNIX commands tar(1) and compress(1) and is compatible with PKZIP (Phil Katz's ZIP). A companion program (unzip(1L)), unpacks zip archives.

packages.name: inih
packages.descl: inih (INI Not Invented Here)** is a simple .INI file parser written in C. It's only a couple of pages of code, and it was designed to be small and simple, so it's good for embedded systems. It's also more or less compatible with Python's ConfigParser style of .INI files, including RFC 822-style multi-line syntax and `name: value` entries.  Homepage: https://github.com/benhoyt/inih

packages.name: inotify-tools
packages.descl: inotify-tools is a set of command-line programs for Linux providing a simple interface to inotify. These programs can be used to monitor and act upon filesystem events.  For more information see the inotifywait and inotifywatch man pages.  Homepage: http://wiki.github.com/rvoicilas/inotify-tools/

packages.name: intel-vaapi-driver
packages.descs: intel-vaapi-driver (VA driver for Intel G45 & HD Graphics family)
packages.descl: intel-vaapi-driver is the VA-API implementation for Intel G45 chipsets and Intel HD Graphics for Intel Core processor family.  Homepage: https://01.org/linuxmedia/vaapi

packages.name: intltool
packages.descl: This package contains scripts and autoconf files for internationalizing data.  Homepage: https://edge.launchpad.net/intltool

packages.name: inxi
packages.descl: inxi is a command line system information script built for console and IRC. It is also used a debugging tool for forum technical support to quickly ascertain users' system configurations and hardware. inxi shows system hardware, CPU, drivers, Xorg, Desktop, Kernel, gcc version(s), processes, RAM usage, and a wide variety of other useful information.  Homepage: https://github.com/smxi/inxi

packages.name: iproute2
packages.descl: These are tools used to administer many advanced IP routing features in the kernel. See Configure.help in the kernel documentation (search for iproute2) for more information on which kernel options these tools are used with.  These utilities were written by Alexey Kuznetsov. The current maintainer of iproute2 is Stephen Hemminger.

packages.name: ipset
packages.descs: ipset (administration tool for kernel IP sets)
packages.descl: IP sets are a Linux kernel framework administered by the ipset utility. Depending on the type, currently an IP set may store IP addresses, (TCP/UDP) port numbers, or IP addresses with MAC addresses in a way which ensures lightning speed when matching an entry against a set.  Homepage: http://ipset.netfilter.org/

packages.name: iptables
packages.descl: Iptables can be used to build internet firewalls based on stateless and stateful packet filtering, use NAT and masquerading for sharing internet access if you don't have enough public IP addresses, use NAT to implement transparent proxies, aid the tc and iproute2 systems used to build sophisticated QoS and policy routers, do further packet manipulation (mangling) like altering the TOS/DSCP/ECN bits of the IP header, and much more.  Homepage: http://www.netfilter.org/projects/iptables/

packages.name: iptraf-ng
packages.descl: IPTraf is a console-based network monitoring program for Linux that displays information about IP traffic such as:  Current TCP connections, types of IP packets, packet and byte counts, TCP/UDP counts by ports, packet counts by packet sizes, packet and byte counts by IP address, interface activity, flag statuses on TCP packets, and other LAN station statistics.  iptraf-ng was written by Gerard Paul Java.

packages.name: iputils
packages.descs: iputils (a collection of common network tools)
packages.descl: The iputils package contains network tools found on nearly all *NIX systems, along with an extra or two. Some of the utilities found here include arping, clockdiff, ping, ping6, rarpd, rdisc, tracepath, and tracepath6.  iputils is maintained by YOSHIFUJI Hideaki.

packages.name: ipw2100-fw
packages.descl: This firmware is used by the ipw2100 kernel module for the Intel PRO/Wireless 2100 Network Connection mini PCI adapter. Your use of this firmware is governed by this Intel license: /usr/doc/ipw2100-fw-1.3/LICENSE  Visit Intel's Linux wireless website at this address: http://intellinuxwireless.org/

packages.name: ipw2200-fw
packages.descl: This firmware is used by the ipw2200 kernel module for the Intel PRO/Wireless 2915ABG Network Connection and Intel PRO/Wireless 2200BG Network Connection mini PCI adapters. Your use of this firmware is governed by this Intel license: /usr/doc/ipw2200-fw-3.1/LICENSE  Visit Intel's Linux wireless website at this address: http://intellinuxwireless.org/

packages.name: irssi
packages.descl: Irssi is an Internet Relay Chat client. Designed to be both secure and expandable, irssi is easily customized using modules and scripts.  For more information, visit: http://irssi.org  irssi was written by Timo Sirainen.

packages.name: isl
packages.descl: isl is a thread-safe C library for manipulating sets and relations of integer points bounded by affine constraints. The descriptions of the sets and relations may involve both parameters and existentially quantified variables. All computations are performed in exact integer arithmetic using GMP.  Homepage: http://isl.gforge.inria.fr

packages.name: iso-codes
packages.descl: This package provides lists of various ISO standards (e.g. country, language, language scripts, and currency names) in one place, rather than repeated in many programs throughout the system.  Homepage: https://salsa.debian.org/iso-codes-team/iso-codes

packages.name: ispell
packages.descl: Ispell is a fast screen-oriented spelling checker that shows you your errors in the context of the original file, and suggests possible corrections when it can figure them out. Compared to UNIX spell, it is faster and much easier to use. Ispell can also handle languages other than English. Ispell has a long history, and many people have contributed to the current version -- some of the major contributors include R. E. Gorin, Pace Willisson, Walt Buehring, and Geoff Kuenning.

packages.name: itinerary
packages.descs: itinerary (Itinerary and boarding pass management app)
packages.descl: KDE Itinerary is a digital travel assistant with a priority on protecting your privacy.  Homepage: https://apps.kde.org/en/itinerary

packages.name: itstool
packages.descs: itstool (Translate XML documents with PO files)
packages.descl: ITS Tool allows you to translate your XML documents with PO files, using rules from the W3C Internationalization Tag Set (ITS) to determine what to translate and how to separate it into PO file messages.  Homepage: http://itstool.org/

packages.name: iw
packages.descs: iw (tool for configuring Linux wireless devices)
packages.descl: This package contains the `iw' tool which allows you to configure and show information about wireless networking. The tool is currently used for drivers based on the mac80211 stack, but work is under way to make it useful for other wireless drivers as well.  Homepage: http://wireless.kernel.org/en/users/Documentation/iw

packages.name: jansson
packages.descl: Jansson is a C library for encoding, decoding and manipulating JSON data. It features a simple and intuitive API and data model, includes full Unicode support, and has no dependencies on other libraries (except for glibc).  Homepage: http://www.digip.org/jansson/

packages.name: jasper
packages.descs: jasper (free implementation of the JPEG-2000 standard)
packages.descl: The JasPer Project is an open-source initiative to provide a free software-based reference implementation of the codec specified in the JPEG-2000 Part-1 standard (i.e., ISO/IEC 15444-1).  Homepage: http://www.ece.uvic.ca/~mdadams/jasper/

packages.name: jed
packages.descl: JED (by John E. Davis) is an extremely powerful but small emacs-like programmer's editor that is extensible in a C-like macro language and can do color syntax highlighting. Among the many features: Emacs, wordstar, EDT emulation; C, Fortran, TeX, text editing modes; Full undo; GNU Emacs compatible info reader, and lots more.  JED is also 8 bit clean, so you can even edit binary files!

packages.name: jemalloc
packages.descl: jemalloc is a general-purpose scalable concurrent malloc(3) implementation.  Homepage: http://jemalloc.net

packages.name: jfsutils
packages.descl: Utilities for managing IBM's Journaled File System (JFS) under Linux: jfs_debugfs - shell-type JFS file system editor. jfs_fsck - check and repair a JFS formatted device. jfs_fscklog - extract a JFS fsck service log into a file. jfs_logdump - dump a JFS formatted device's journal log. jfs_mkfs - create a JFS formatted partition. jfs_tune - adjust tunable file system parameters on JFS.

packages.name: jmtpfs
packages.descs: jmtpfs (FUSE and libmtp based filesystem for MTP)
packages.descl: jmtpfs is a FUSE and libmtp based filesystem for accessing MTP (Media Transfer Protocol) devices. It was specifically designed for exchanging files between Linux (and Mac OS X) systems and newer Android devices that support MTP but not USB Mass Storage.  Homepage: https://github.com/JasonFerrara/jmtpfs

packages.name: joe
packages.descl: Joseph H. Allen's easy to use text editor, similar to WordStar[tm].  Homepage: http://joe-editor.sourceforge.net

packages.name: jove
packages.descl: A mostly Emacs compatible text editor, with man pages and the 'teachjove' tutorial program. If you'd rather have the real thing, the actual Emacs editor/environment is available in series 'E'.  JOVE was written by Jonathan Payne.

packages.name: json-c
packages.descl: JSON-C implements a reference counting object model that allows you to easily construct JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) objects in C, output them as JSON formatted strings and parse JSON formatted strings back into the C representation of JSON objects. It aims to conform to RFC 7159.  Homepage: https://github.com/json-c/json-c

packages.name: json-glib
packages.descl: JSON-GLib implements a full JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) parser and generator using GLib and GObject, and integrates JSON with GLib data types.  Homepage: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/json-glib/

packages.name: judy
packages.descl: Judy is a C library that provides a state-of-the-art core technology that implements a sparse dynamic array. A Judy array consumes memory only when it is populated, yet can grow to take advantage of all available memory if desired. Judy's key benefits are scalability, high performance, and memory efficiency.  homepage: http://judy.sourceforge.net

packages.name: juk
packages.descl: JuK is an audio jukebox application, supporting collections of MP3, Ogg Vorbis, and FLAC audio files. It allows you to edit the tags of your audio files and manage your collection and playlists. In fact, its main focus is on music management.

packages.name: k3b
packages.descl: K3b makes writing cds under Linux easy. It has an easy to use interface and supports CD burning (including on-the-fly), copying, erasing, ripping, and more.  K3b was written by Sebastian Trueg, Thomas Froescher, Christian Kvasny, and Klaus-Dieter Krannich.  Homepage: http://www.k3b.org

packages.name: kactivities
packages.descl: API for using and interacting with Activities as a consumer, application adding information to them, or as an activity manager.

packages.name: kactivities-stats
packages.descl: kactivities-stats is library for accessing the usage data collected by the Activities system.

packages.name: kactivitymanagerd
packages.descl: System service to manage user activities and track the usage patterns.  Homepage: https://projects.kde.org/projects/kde/workspace/kactivitymanagerd

packages.name: kaddressbook
packages.descl: KDE contact manager.

packages.name: kalarm
packages.descl: Personal alarm scheduler.

packages.name: kalarmcal
packages.descl: kalarmcal contains the KAlarm client library.

packages.name: kalgebra
packages.descl: KAlgebra is a MathML-based graph calculator. It was initially MathML oriented, but now it can be used by anyone with a little mathematical knowledge.

packages.name: kalzium
packages.descl: Kalzium shows a periodic table of the elements.

packages.name: kamera
packages.descl: Digital camera support for KDE.

packages.name: kamoso
packages.descl: Kamoso is a great program to use your webcam to take pictures or make videos. It probably should be the best webcam recorder for Linux.  Kamoso can make photos from your webcam and upload them to Facebook. It also allows to record videos from your webcam and upload them to YouTube.  Homepage: https://userbase.kde.org/Kamoso

packages.name: kanagram
packages.descl: Kanagram is a replacement for KMessedWords. Kanagram mixes up the letters of a word to create an anagram, and you have to guess what the mixed up word is. Kanagram features several built-in word lists, hints, and a cheat feature which reveals the original word. Kanagram also has a vocabulary editor.

packages.name: kapidox
packages.descl: This framework contains scripts and data for building API documentation (dox) in a standard format and style.

packages.name: kapman
packages.descs: kapman (KDE version of dot-eating arcade game)
packages.descl: Kapman is a clone of the well known arcade game where you must run through a maze to eat all pills without being captured by a ghost. By eating an energizer, Kapman gets the ability to eat ghosts for a few seconds. When a stage is cleared of pills and energizers the player is taken to the next stage with slightly increased game speed.

packages.name: kapptemplate
packages.descl: KAppTemplate is a shell script to create the necessary framework to develop KDE applications.

packages.name: karchive
packages.descl: KArchive provides classes for easy reading, creation and manipulation of archive formats like ZIP and TAR. It also provides transparent compression and decompression of data, like the GZip format, via a subclass of QIODevice.

packages.name: kate
packages.descs: kate (an advanced text editor for KDE)
packages.descl: The Kate project develops two main products: KatePart, the advanced editor component which is used in numerous KDE applications requiring a text editing component, and Kate, a MDI text editor application. In addition, it provides KWrite, a simple SDI editor shell which allows the user to select his/her favorite editor component.  Homepage: http://kate-editor.org

packages.name: katomic
packages.descl: Katomic is both fun and educational game built around molecular geometry. It employs simplistic two-dimensional looks at different chemical elements. You can also play an online demo version of this game.

packages.name: kauth
packages.descl: KAuth provides a convenient, system-integrated way to offload actions that need to be performed as a privileged user (root, for example) to small (hopefully secure) helper utilities.

packages.name: kbackup
packages.descl: KBackup is an application that lets you back up any folders or files in a tar archive to a local folder, e.g. a locally mounted device like a ZIP drive, USB stick, etc. or a remote URL. KBackup can also run automated backups without using a graphical user interface.  Homepage: https://www.kde.org/applications/utilities/kbackup/

packages.name: kbd
packages.descl: Load and save keyboard mappings. Needed if you are not using the US keyboard map. This package also contains utilities to change your console fonts - if you install it you'll get a menu later on that lets you select from many different fonts. If you like one, you can make it your default font. A new default font can be chosen at any time by typing 'setconsolefont'.

packages.name: kblackbox
packages.descs: kblackbox (a game of hide and seek)
packages.descl: KBlackbox is a game of hide and seek played on a grid of boxes where the computer has hidden several balls.

packages.name: kblocks
packages.descl: KBlocks is the KDE version of the classic falling blocks game.

packages.name: kbookmarks
packages.descl: KBookmarks lets you access and manipulate bookmarks stored using the XBEL format. The most common use for bookmarks is web browsers, but this can also be useful in any application where local files or URLs can be saved as bookmarks.  For more information on the XBEL format, see: http://pyxml.sourceforge.net/topics/xbel/

packages.name: kbounce
packages.descl: KBounce is a single player arcade game with the elements of puzzle. It is played on a field, surrounded by wall, with two or more balls that move about in the field bouncing off of walls. The player can build new walls, decreasing the size of active field.

packages.name: kbreakout
packages.descl: KBreakout is the KDE version of a Breakout-like game.

packages.name: kbruch
packages.descl: KBruch is a small program to practice calculating with fractions.

packages.name: kcachegrind
packages.descs: kcachegrind (GUI to profilers such as Valgrind)
packages.descl: kcachegrind is a graphical browser for data produced by profiling tools such as Valgrind.

packages.name: kcalc
packages.descl: KCalc is a calculator which offers many more mathematical functions than meet the eye on a first glance.  Homepage: http://utils.kde.org/projects/kcalc

packages.name: kcalendarcore
packages.descl: This library provides access to and handling of calendar data. It supports the standard formats iCalendar and vCalendar and the group scheduling standard iTIP.

packages.name: kcalutils
packages.descl: This library provides a set of utility functions that help applications access and use calendar data via the KCalCore library.

packages.name: kcharselect
packages.descl: KCharSelect is a tool to select special characters from all installed fonts and copy them into the clipboard.  Homepage: http://utils.kde.org/projects/kcharselect

packages.name: kcm-fcitx
packages.descl: kcm-fcitx is a configuration tool that is highly integrated with KDE.  Features: - Change input method list - Change global configuration - Change addon configuration and enable/disable addon. - Download skin from kde-look.org  Homepage: http://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Kcm

packages.name: kcmutils
packages.descl: KCMUtils provides various classes to work with KCModules. KCModules can be created with the KConfigWidgets framework.

packages.name: kcodecs
packages.descl: KCodecs provide a collection of methods to manipulate strings using various encodings. It can automatically determine the charset of a string, translate XML entities, validate email addresses, and find encodings by name in a more tolerant way than QTextCodec (useful e.g. for data coming from the Internet).

packages.name: kcolorchooser
packages.descl: A color chooser application for KDE.

packages.name: kcompletion
packages.descl: When typing filenames, email addresses and other text where the user often wants to select from existing data (including what they previously typed) rather than enter anything wholly original, users often find it helpful if they only need to type the first few characters, and then have the application offer them a set of choices or attempt to finish off what they were typing. This framework helps implement this in Qt-based applications.

packages.name: kconfig
packages.descl: KConfig provides an advanced configuration system. It is made of two parts: KConfigCore and KConfigGui. KConfigCore provides access to the configuration files themselves. KConfigGui provides a way to hook widgets to the configuration so that they are automatically initialized from the configuration and automatically propagate their changes to their respective configuration files.

packages.name: kconfigwidgets
packages.descl: KConfigWidgets provides easy-to-use classes to create configuration dialogs, as well as a set of widgets which uses KConfig to store their settings.

packages.name: kcontacts
packages.descl: kcontacts contains an address book API for KDE. This can be used by all KDE applications using data of this type, e.g. KAddressBook, KMail, KOrganizer, KPilot etc.

packages.name: kcoreaddons
packages.descl: KCoreAddons provides classes built on top of QtCore to perform various tasks such as manipulating mime types, autosaving files, creating backup files, generating random sequences, performing text manipulations such as macro replacement, accessing user information and many more.

packages.name: kcrash
packages.descl: KCrash provides support for intercepting and handling application crashes.

packages.name: kcron
packages.descl: kcron is a module for scheduling programs to run in the background. It is a graphical user interface to cron, the UNIX system scheduler.

packages.name: kdav
packages.descl: The DAV protocol extends HTTP with new methods that allow a DAV client to create, modify, and update files and directories in the server. KDAV provides a DAV protocol implemention with KJobs. Calendars and todos are supported, using either GroupDAV or CalDAV, and contacts are supported using GroupDAV or CardDAV.

packages.name: kdbusaddons
packages.descl: KDBusAddons provides convenience classes on top of QtDBus, as well as an API to create KDED modules.

packages.name: kde-cli-tools
packages.descl: Tools based on KDE Frameworks 5 to better interact with the system.

packages.name: kde-dev-scripts
packages.descs: kde-dev-scripts (scripts for development of KDE software)
packages.descl: Scripts and setting files useful during development of KDE software.

packages.name: kde-dev-utils
packages.descl: Small utilities for developers using KDE/Qt libs/frameworks such as kmtrace, kpartloader, kprofilemethod, kstartperf, kuiviewer.

packages.name: kde-gtk-config
packages.descl: System settings kcm to set GTK application look and feel in KDE.  Homepage: http://projects.kde.org/kde-gtk-config

packages.name: kdebugsettings
packages.descl: kdebugsettings is an application to enable/disable qCDebug.

packages.name: kdeclarative
packages.descs: kdeclarative (Integration of QML and KDE workspaces)
packages.descl: KDeclarative provides integration of QML and KDE work spaces. It comprises two parts: a library used by the C++ part of your application to intergrate QML with KDE Frameworks specific features, and a series of QML imports that offer bindings to some of the frameworks.

packages.name: kdeconnect-kde
packages.descs: kdeconnect-kde (Integrate Android with the Plasma Desktop)
packages.descl: KDE Connect is a module to connect KDE with your smartphone. Prominent features are: clipboard share, notifications sync, multimedia remote control over secured network connections. Please note you will need to install KDE Connect on Android for this app to work:  https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.kde.kdeconnect_tp

packages.name: kdecoration
packages.descs: kdecoration (library to create themes for kwin)
packages.descl: This library makes it easier and more reliable to make themes for KWin, Plasma's window manager. It has impressive memory, performance and stability improvements.

packages.name: kded
packages.descl: KDED stands for KDE Daemon. KDED runs in the background and performs a number of small tasks. Some of these tasks are built in, others are started on demand. Examples include checking for newly installed software and checking for newly installed update files.

packages.name: kdeedu-data
packages.descs: kdeedu-data (icons, artwork and data files for KDE edu)
packages.descl: Shared icons, artwork and data files for educational applications.

packages.name: kdegraphics-mobipocket
packages.descl: Mobipocket support for Okular.

packages.name: kdegraphics-thumbnailers
packages.descl: These plugins allow KDE software to create thumbnails for several graphic file formats.

packages.name: kdelibs4support
packages.descl: kdelibs4support provides legacy support for kdelibs 4 compatibility such as code and utilities to ease the transition from kdelibs 4 to KDE Frameworks 5. This includes CMake macros and C++ classes whose functionality has been replaced by code in CMake, Qt and other frameworks.

packages.name: kdenetwork-filesharing
packages.descs: kdenetwork-filesharing (share a directory with the local network)
packages.descl: Konqueror properties dialog plugin to share a directory with the local network.

packages.name: kdenlive
packages.descl: A non-linear video editor for Linux using the MLT video framework.  Homepage: http://www.kdenlive.org

packages.name: kdepim-addons
packages.descl: Addons for KDE PIM applications.

packages.name: kdepim-runtime
packages.descl: The KDE-PIM project aims to bring together those who wish to help design, implement, test, etc. anything that's to do with personal information management.  This rather broad scope encompasses mail clients, addressbooks, usenet news, scheduling, and even sticky notes.

packages.name: kdeplasma-addons
packages.descl: Plasmoids (or widgets) for the KDE Plasma Desktop shell.

packages.name: kdesdk-kioslaves
packages.descl: This package contains KIO-slaves for KDE SDK.

packages.name: kdesdk-thumbnailers
packages.descl: Thumbnailers for KDE, including gnu gettext po translation files and gettext translation templates.

packages.name: kdesignerplugin
packages.descs: kdesignerplugin (Integrate custom widgets with Qt Designer)
packages.descl: This framework provides a utility (kgendesignerplugin) that can be used to generate plugins for Qt Designer from ini-style description files.

packages.name: kdesu
packages.descl: KDESU provides functionality for building GUI front ends for (password asking) console mode programs. For example, kdesu and kdessh use it to interface with su and ssh respectively.

packages.name: kdev-php
packages.descl: This is a KDevelop plugin that provides support for the PHP language.

packages.name: kdev-python
packages.descl: This KDevelop plugin provides support for the Python language.

packages.name: kdevelop
packages.descl: The KDevelop integrated C/C++ application development environment.

packages.name: kdevelop-pg-qt
packages.descl: KDevelop Parser Generator used in the PHP language plugin and others.

packages.name: kdewebkit
packages.descl: This library provides KDE integration of the QtWebKit library. If you are using QtWebKit in your KDE application, you are encouraged to use this layer instead of using the QtWebKit classes directly. In particular, you should use KWebView in place of QWebView, KGraphicsWebView in place of QGraphicsWebView and KWebPage in place of QWebPage. See the documentation for more information.

packages.name: kdf
packages.descl: kdf (KDiskFree) displays the available file devices (hard drive partitions, floppy and CD/DVD drives, etc.) along with information on their capacity, free space, type and mount point.  Homepage: http://utils.kde.org/projects/kdf

packages.name: kdiagram
packages.descl: Powerful libraries (KChart, KGantt) for creating business diagrams.  Homepage: https://github.com/KDE/kdiagram

packages.name: kdialog
packages.descl: A utility for displaying dialog boxes from shell scripts.

packages.name: kdiamond
packages.descl: KDiamond is a single player puzzle game. The object of the game is to build and remove lines of three similar diamonds.

packages.name: kdnssd
packages.descl: A network monitor for DNS-SD services (Zeroconf).

packages.name: kdoctools
packages.descl: KDocTools provides tools to generate documentation in various formats from DocBook files.

packages.name: kdsoap
packages.descl: KD SOAP is a tool for creating client applications for web services. It also provides the means to create web services without the need for any further component such as a dedicated web server. It makes it possible to interact with applications which have APIs that can be exported as SOAP objects. The web service then provides a machine- accessible interface to its functionality via HTTP.  Homepage: https://www.kdab.com/development-resources/qt-tools/kd-soap/

packages.name: keditbookmarks
packages.descl: Bookmark organizer and editor.

packages.name: kemoticons
packages.descs: kemoticons (Convert text emoticons to graphical emoticons)
packages.descl: KEmoticons converts emoticons from text to a graphical representation with images in HTML. It supports setting different themes for emoticons coming from different providers.

packages.name: kernel-firmware
packages.descl: These are firmware files for the Linux kernel.  You'll need these to use certain hardware drivers with Linux.  Upstream site:  git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/firmware/linux-firmware.git

packages.name: kernel-generic
packages.descs: kernel-generic (a general purpose SMP Linux kernel)
packages.descl: This is a Linux kernel with built-in support for most disk controllers. To use filesystems, or to load support for a SCSI or other controller, then you'll need to load one or more kernel modules using an initial ramdisk, or initrd. For more information about creating an initrd, see the README.initrd file in the /boot directory.  SMP is 'Symmetric multiprocessing', or multiple CPU/core support.

packages.name: kernel-headers
packages.descl: These are the include files from the Linux kernel.  You'll need these to compile most system software for Linux.

packages.name: kernel-huge
packages.descl: This is a Linux kernel with built-in support for most disk controllers. If you're looking for a more stripped down kernel (this one contains everything but the kitchen sink ;-), then install the kernel-generic in the /boot directory along with an initrd to load support for your boot device and filesystem. For instructions on the initrd, see README.initrd in the /boot directory.  SMP is 'Symmetric multiprocessing', or multiple CPU/core support.

packages.name: kernel-modules
packages.descl: Kernel modules are pieces of code that can be loaded and unloaded into the kernel upon demand. They extend the functionality of the kernel without the need to reboot the system. These modules provide support for hardware such as USB devices, RAID controllers, network interfaces, and display devices, or add other additional capabilities to the kernel.

packages.name: kernel-source
packages.descl: Source code for Linus Torvalds' Linux kernel.  This is the complete and unmodified source code for the Linux kernel.

packages.name: keybinder3
packages.descs: keybinder3 (keyboard shortcut library for GTK+ v3)
packages.descl: keybinder is a library for registering global keyboard shortcuts. Keybinder works with GTK-based applications using the X Window System.  Homepage: https://github.com/engla/keybinder

packages.name: keyutils
packages.descl: This package contains tools and a wrapper library to control the Linux kernel key management facility and to provide a mechanism by which the kernel can call back to user space to get a key instantiated.  Homepage: http://people.redhat.com/~dhowells/keyutils/

packages.name: kfilemetadata
packages.descs: kfilemetadata (a library for extracting file metadata)
packages.descl: KFileMetaData provides a simple library for extracting the text and metadata from a number of different files. This library is typically used by file indexers to retreive the metadata. This library can also be used by applications to write metadata.

packages.name: kfind
packages.descs: kfind (find files and directories in KDE)
packages.descl: The Find Files tool is a useful method of searching for specific files on your computer, or for searching for files that match a pattern. An example of this could include searching for files of a particular type or with certain letters in the filename, or that contain a certain piece of text in their contents.

packages.name: kfloppy
packages.descl: KFloppy is a utility that provides a straightforward graphical means to format 3.5' and 5.25' floppy disks.  Homepage: http://utils.kde.org/projects/kfloppy

packages.name: kfourinline
packages.descl: KFourInLine is a board game for two players based on the Connect-Four game. The players try to build up a row of four pieces using different strategies.

packages.name: kgamma5
packages.descl: A KDE system settings module to configure display gamma.

packages.name: kgeography
packages.descl: KGeography is a geography learning tool with three usage modes:  Browse the maps clicking in a map division to see it's name. The game tells you a map division name and you have to click on it. The game shows you a map division flag and you have to guess its name.  Homepage: http://kgeography.berlios.de/

packages.name: kget
packages.descl: kget is a download manager for KDE.

packages.name: kglobalaccel
packages.descl: KGlobalAccel allows you to have global accelerators that are independent of the focused window. Unlike regular shortcuts, the application's window does not need focus for them to be activated.

packages.name: kgoldrunner
packages.descs: kgoldrunner (Hunt gold, dodge enemies and solve puzzles)
packages.descl: KGoldrunner is a maze-threading game with a puzzle flavor. It has hundreds of levels where pieces of gold must be collected, with enemies in hot pursuit.

packages.name: kgpg
packages.descl: KGpg is a simple interface for GnuPG, a powerful encryption utility.  Homepage: http://utils.kde.org/projects/kgpg

packages.name: kguiaddons
packages.descl: The KDE GUI addons provide utilities for graphical user interfaces in the areas of colors, fonts, text, images, and keyboard input.

packages.name: khangman
packages.descl: KHangman is the classical hangman game. The child should guess a word letter by letter. At each miss, the picture of a hangman appears. After 10 tries, if the word is not guessed, the game is over and the answer is displayed.

packages.name: khelpcenter
packages.descl: The KDE Help Center displays documentation on how to use the KDE plasma workspaces and applications, as well as man and info pages. It can search through documentation using the 'htdig' package.

packages.name: kholidays
packages.descs: kholidays (KDE library for regional holiday information)
packages.descl: The KHolidays library in kdepimlibs provides details on public holidays for a given country and date range. A separate library and file format is required as iCalendar is not capable of expressing recurrence rules for all possible holidays.

packages.name: khotkeys
packages.descl: The Custom Shortcuts systemsettings module allows you to configure custom keyboard shortcuts and mouse gestures. You can use them to control applications, run specific commands, and more.

packages.name: khtml
packages.descl: KHTML is a web rendering engine based on the KParts technology and using KJS for JavaScript support.

packages.name: ki18n
packages.descl: KI18n provides functionality for internationalizing user interface text in applications, based on the GNU Gettext translation system. It wraps the standard Gettext functionality, so that the programmers and translators can use the familiar Gettext tools and workflows. KI18n also provides argument capturing, customizable markup, and translation scripting.

packages.name: kiconthemes
packages.descl: The KIconThemes library contains classes to improve the handling of icons in applications using the KDE Frameworks.

packages.name: kid3
packages.descl: If you want to easily tag multiple MP3, Ogg/Vorbis, FLAC, MPC, MP4/AAC, MP2, Opus, Speex, TrueAudio, WavPack, WMA, WAV and AIFF files (e.g. full albums) without typing the same information again and again and have control over both ID3v1 and ID3v2 tags, then Kid3 is the program you are looking for.  Homepage: http://kid3.kde.org/

packages.name: kidentitymanagement
packages.descl: kidentitymanagement contains the KIdentityManagement Library.

packages.name: kidletime
packages.descl: KIdleTime is a singleton reporting information on idle time. It is useful not only for finding out about the current idle time of the system, but also for getting notified upon idle time events, such as custom timeouts or user activity.

packages.name: kig
packages.descl: Kig is an application meant to allow high school students to interactively explore mathematical concepts, much like Dr.Geo, KGeo, KSeg and Cabri.  Homepage: http://edu.kde.org/kig/

packages.name: kigo
packages.descl: Kigo is an open-source implementation of the popular Go game. Go is a strategic board game for two players. It is also known as igo (Japanese), weiqi or wei ch'i (Chinese) or baduk (Korean). Go is noted for being rich in strategic complexity despite its simple rules. The game is played by two players who alternately place black and white pieces on the vacant intersections of a grid of 19x19 lines (9x9 or 13x13 for easier games).

packages.name: kile
packages.descl: kile is a user-friendly TeX/LaTeX editor for the KDE desktop environment.  Homepage: https://kile.sourceforge.io

packages.name: killbots
packages.descl: Killbots is a simple game of evading killer robots.

packages.name: kimageformats
