packages.descl: WavPack is a completely open audio compression format providing lossless, high-quality lossy, and a unique hybrid compression mode. The hybrid mode creates both a relatively small, high-quality lossy file that can be used all by itself, and a 'correction' file that (when combined with the lossy file) provides full lossless restoration.  Homepage: http://www.wavpack.com

packages.name: wayland
packages.descl: Wayland is protocol for a compositor to talk to its clients as well as a library implementation of the protocol. The compositor can be a standalone display server running on Linux kernel modesetting and evdev input devices, an X application, or a wayland client itself. The clients can be traditional applications, X servers (rootless or fullscreen) or other display servers.  Homepage: https://wayland.freedesktop.org/

packages.name: wayland-protocols
packages.descl: wayland-protocols contains Wayland protocols that add functionality not available in the Wayland core protocol. Such protocols either add completely new functionality, or extend the functionality of some other protocol either in Wayland core or in wayland-protocols.  Homepage: https://wayland.freedesktop.org/

packages.name: wget
packages.descl: GNU Wget is a free network utility to retrieve files from the World Wide Web using HTTP and FTP, the two most widely used Internet protocols. It works non-interactively, thus enabling work in the background after having logged off.  The author of Wget is Hrvoje Niksic <hniksic@srce.hr>.

packages.name: wget2
packages.descl: GNU Wget2 is the successor of GNU Wget, a file and recursive website downloader. Designed and written from scratch it wraps around libwget, that provides the basic functions needed by a web client. In many cases Wget2 downloads much faster than Wget1.x due to HTTP2, HTTP compression, parallel connections and use of If-Modified-Since HTTP header.  Design and implementation by Tim Rhsen, with lead maintainers Tim Rhsen, Darshit Shah, and Giuseppe Scrivano.

packages.name: which
packages.descs: which (shows the full path to shell commands)
packages.descl: GNU 'which' takes one or more arguments. For each of its arguments it prints to stdout the full path of the executables that would have been executed when this argument had been entered at the shell prompt. It does this by searching for an executable or script in the directories listed in the environment variable PATH using the same algorithm as bash(1). 'Which' is a built-in function in many shells.  The GNU version of which was written by Carlo Wood.

packages.name: whois
packages.descl: This is an enhanced whois (RFC 954) client derived from the BSD and RIPE whois programs. It can automatically select the appropriate whois server for most queries.  This version of whois was written by Marco d'Itri.  Homepage: http://www.linux.it/~md/software/

packages.name: windowmaker
packages.descs: windowmaker (a fast and elegant window manager)
packages.descl: Window Maker is a window manager for the X Window System that is relatively fast and small, feature rich, easy to use, with a simple and elegant appearance reminiscent of the NeXTSTEP(tm) graphical user interface.  Window Maker is part of the official GNU project.

packages.name: wireguard-tools
packages.descl: This supplies the main userspace tooling for using and configuring WireGuard tunnels, including the wg(8) and wg-quick(8) utilities.  For more information about WireGuard, see: https://www.wireguard.com/  Homepage: https://git.zx2c4.com/wireguard-tools

packages.name: wireless_tools
packages.descl: This package contains tools and a library used for configuring wireless networking interfaces: iwconfig (the main wireless tool),  iwlist (display more detailed information than iwconfig),  iwspy (get stats per MAC address and more),  iwpriv (set driver private ioctls),  iwgetid (show the ESSID or NWID of a device),  iwevent (display wireless events), ifrename (rename a network interface).  The wireless_tools were written by Jean Tourrilhes.

packages.name: woff2
packages.descl: WOFF2 is the Web Open Font Format 2 reference implementation. See also: https://www.w3.org/TR/WOFF2/  Homepage: https://github.com/google/woff2

packages.name: wpa_supplicant
packages.descl: wpa_supplicant is a WPA Supplicant for Linux with support for WPA and WPA2 (IEEE 802.11i / RSN). Supplicant is the IEEE 802.1X/WPA component that is used in the client stations. It implements key negotiation with a WPA Authenticator and it controls the roaming and IEEE 802.11 authentication/association of the wlan driver.  Homepage: http://hostap.epitest.fi/wpa_supplicant/

packages.name: wqy-zenhei-font-ttf
packages.descs: wqy-zenhei-font-ttf (Wen Quan Yi Zen Hei CJK Font)
packages.descl: The WenQuanYi Zen Hei font is a Chinese (or CJK) outline font with Hei Ti style (a sans-serif style) Hanzi glyphs. This font is developed for general purpose use of Chinese for formating, printing and on-screen display. This font is also targeted at platform independence and the utility for document exchange between various operating systems.  Homepage: https://sourceforge.net/projects/wqy/files/

packages.name: x11-skel
packages.descl: These are some symlinks needed by X11 after moving some files and directories to conform with the Linux FHS. For example, the fonts are now in the /usr/share/fonts directory, and this package makes a symlink to there from /usr/lib/X11/fonts (the default location). An /etc/xdg directory (the default for XDG_CONFIG_DIRS in the XDG Base Directory Specification) is also contained in this package, as well as sample xorg.conf files and other scripts.

packages.name: x11-ssh-askpass
packages.descl: x11-ssh-askpass is an X11-based passphrase dialog for use with OpenSSH.

packages.name: x11perf
packages.descl: x11perf is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: x3270
packages.descs: x3270 (IBM host access tool for X)
packages.descl: x3270 opens a telnet connection to an IBM host in an X window. Since the window created by x3270 can use its own font for displaying characters, is a fairly accurate representation of an IBM 3278.

packages.name: xaos
packages.descl: XaoS is a fast portable real-time interactive fractal zoomer. It displays the Mandelbrot set (and other popular fractals), and allows the user to smoothly zoom in or out of a fractal. Other features include autopilot mode, palette changing, PNG saving, and fractal inversion.  Homepage: https://github.com/xaos-project/XaoS

packages.name: xapian-core
packages.descl: Xapian is an Open Source Probabilistic Information Retrieval Library. It offers a highly adaptable toolkit that allows developers to easily add advanced indexing and search facilities to applications.  Homepage: http://www.xapian.org/

packages.name: xauth
packages.descl: The xauth program is used to edit and display the authorization information used in connecting to the X server.

packages.name: xbacklight
packages.descs: xbacklight (adjust the backlight brightness where supported)
packages.descl: It uses the RandR extension to find all outputs on the X server supporting backlight brightness control and changes them all in the same way.

packages.name: xbiff
packages.descl: xbiff provides graphical notification of new e-mail. It only handles mail stored in a filesystem accessible file, not via IMAP, POP or other remote access protocols.

packages.name: xbitmaps
packages.descl: xbitmaps is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xcalc
packages.descl: xcalc is a scientific calculator X11 client that can emulate a TI-30 or an HP-10C.

packages.name: xcb-proto
packages.descs: xcb-proto (X protocol C-language Binding protocol descriptions)
packages.descl: xcb-proto provides the XML-XCB protocol descriptions that libxcb uses to generate the majority of its code and API. We provide them separately from libxcb to allow reuse by other projects, such as additional language bindings, protocol dissectors, or documentation generators.

packages.name: xcb-util
packages.descs: xcb-util (utility libraries for X protocol C-language Binding)
packages.descl: xcb-util is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xcb-util-cursor
packages.descl: The xcb-util-cursor module implements the XCB cursor library, which is the XCB replacement for libXcursor.

packages.name: xcb-util-errors
packages.descl: xcb-util-errors is a utility library that gives human readable names to error codes and event codes and also to major and minor numbers. The necessary information is drawn from xcb-proto's protocol descriptions. This library is especially useful when working with extensions and is mostly useful for debugging.

packages.name: xcb-util-image
packages.descs: xcb-util-image (port of Xlib's XImage and XShmImage functions)
packages.descl: xcb-util-image provides a port of Xlib's XImage and XShmImage functions.

packages.name: xcb-util-keysyms
packages.descl: xcb-util-keysyms provides the keysyms library, which handles standard X key constants and conversion to/from keycodes.

packages.name: xcb-util-renderutil
packages.descl: xcb-util-renderutil provides the XCB renderutil library, which includes some convenience functions for the Render extension.

packages.name: xcb-util-wm
packages.descs: xcb-util-wm (XCB libraries for EWMH and ICCCM)
packages.descl: xcb-util-wm provides the XCB ewmh and iccm libraries, which include client and window manager helpers for EWMH and ICCCM.

packages.name: xclipboard
packages.descl: xclipboard is used to collect and display text selections that are sent to the CLIPBOARD by other clients. It is typically used to save CLIPBOARD selections for later use. It stores each CLIPBOARD selection as a separate string, each of which can be selected.

packages.name: xclock
packages.descl: xclock is the classic X Window System clock utility. It displays the time in analog or digital form, continuously updated at a frequency which may be specified by the user.

packages.name: xcm
packages.descl: Tools based on libXcm, a library for color management on X. xcmddc requests EDID from a monitor over the i2c bus. xcmedid is for parsing EDID data blocks. xcmevents observes X11 color management events.

packages.name: xcmsdb
packages.descl: xcmsdb is used to load, query, or remove Device Color Characterization data stored in properties on the root window of a screen as specified in section 7, Device Color Characterization, of the X11 Inter-Client Communication Conventions Manual (ICCCM).

packages.name: xcompmgr
packages.descl: xcompmgr is a sample compositing manager for X servers supporting the XFIXES, DAMAGE, RENDER, and COMPOSITE extensions. It enables basic eye-candy effects.

packages.name: xconsole
packages.descl: xconsole displays in a X11 window the messages which are usually sent to /dev/console.

packages.name: xcursor-themes
packages.descl: This is a default set of cursor themes for use with libXcursor, originally created for the XFree86 Project, and now shipped as part of the X.Org software distribution.

packages.name: xcursorgen
packages.descs: xcursorgen (prepares X11 cursor sets for use with libXcursor)
packages.descl: xcursorgen is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xdbedizzy
packages.descl: xdbedizzy is a demo of the X11 Double Buffer Extension (DBE) creating a double buffered spinning scene.

packages.name: xdg-desktop-portal
packages.descl: A portal frontend service for Flatpak and possibly other desktop containment frameworks. xdg-desktop-portal works by exposing a series of D-Bus interfaces known as _portals_ under a well-known name (org.freedesktop.portal.Desktop) and object path (/org/freedesktop/portal/desktop). The portal interfaces include APIs for file access, opening URIs, printing and others.

packages.name: xdg-desktop-portal-kde
packages.descl: A backend implementation for xdg-desktop-portal using Qt/KF5.

packages.name: xdg-user-dirs
packages.descl: xdg-user-dirs is a tool used by various XDG compliant desktop environments to locate user well-known user directories such as the Desktop folder. It also handles localization/translation of the filenames.  Homepage: http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/xdg-user-dirs

packages.name: xdg-utils
packages.descs: xdg-utils (command line tools that assist applications)
packages.descl: Xdg-utils is a set of command line tools that assist applications with a variety of desktop integration tasks. About half of the tools focus on tasks commonly required during the installation of a desktop application and the other half focuses on integration with the desktop environment while the application is running.  Homepage: http://portland.freedesktop.org/wiki/

packages.name: xditview
packages.descs: xditview (displays ditroff output on an X display)
packages.descl: xditview is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xdm
packages.descl: xdm is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xdpyinfo
packages.descs: xdpyinfo (utility for displaying information about an X server)
packages.descl: xdpyinfo is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xdriinfo
packages.descs: xdriinfo (query configuration information of X11 DRI drivers)
packages.descl: xdriinfo is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xedit
packages.descl: xedit is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xev
packages.descl: xev creates a window and then asks the X server to send it X11 events whenever anything happens to the window (such as it being moved, resized, typed in, clicked in, etc.). You can also attach it to an existing window. It is useful for seeing what causes events to occur and to display the information that they contain; it is essentially a debugging and development tool, and should not be needed in normal usage.

packages.name: xeyes
packages.descs: xeyes (a follow the mouse X demo, using the X SHAPE extension)
packages.descl: xeyes is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xf86-input-acecad
packages.descs: xf86-input-acecad (Acecad Flair input driver for the Xorg X server)
packages.descl: xf86-input-acecad is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xf86-input-evdev
packages.descs: xf86-input-evdev (Generic Linux input driver for the Xorg X server)
packages.descl: xf86-input-evdev is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xf86-input-joystick
packages.descs: xf86-input-joystick (Joystick input driver for the Xorg X server)
packages.descl: xf86-input-joystick is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xf86-input-keyboard
packages.descs: kbd (Keyboard input driver for the Xorg X server)
packages.descl: This is the non-evdev keyboard driver for X. Most Linux systems should be using the evdev driver to handle input devices such as keyboards and mice, but this driver may be useful as a fallback.

packages.name: xf86-input-libinput

packages.name: xf86-input-mouse

packages.name: xf86dga

packages.descl: xf86dga is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xfce4-appfinder
packages.descl: The Xfce application finder is a tool to find and launch installed applications on your system and execute commands. It can also be used to quickly add launchers to the Xfce Panel by dragging an item from the view and dropping it on the panel.

packages.name: xfce4-clipman-plugin
packages.descs: xfce4-clipman-plugin (clipman plugin for the Xfce panel)
packages.descl: Clipman allows you to keep several clipboard selections in memory which you can then use to toggle. It can pull the clips from both the selection and the copy buffer, restore your clipboard on login, and prevent an empty clipboard.

packages.name: xfce4-dev-tools
packages.descl: The Xfce development tools are a collection of tools and macros for Xfce developers and people that want to build Xfce from Git.

packages.name: xfce4-notifyd
packages.descl: Xfce4-notifyd is a simple, visually-appealing notification daemon for Xfce. Applications can use xfce4-notifyd to pop up a notification bubble by sending messages through D-Bus.

packages.name: xfce4-panel
packages.descl: The Xfce panel is part of the Xfce Desktop Environment and features program launchers, panel menus, a clock, a desktop switcher, and more. Many aspects of the panel can be configured through graphical dialogs, but also by GTK+ style properties and Xfconf settings.

packages.name: xfce4-panel-profiles
packages.descs: xfce4-panel-profiles (simple app to manage Xfce panel layouts)
packages.descl: xfce4-panel-profiles (formerly known as xfpanel-switch) is a simple application to manage Xfce panel layouts.  With the modular Xfce Panel, a multitude of panel layouts can be created. This tool makes it possible to backup, restore, import, and export these panel layouts.  Homepage: https://git.xfce.org/apps/xfce4-panel-profiles

packages.name: xfce4-power-manager
packages.descl: xfce4-power-manager makes power management functions (such as suspend and hibernate) easy inside the Xfce Desktop Environment.

packages.name: xfce4-pulseaudio-plugin
packages.descl: xfce4-pulseaudio-plugin is a plugin for the Xfce panel which provides a convenient way to adjust the audio volume of the PulseAudio sound system and to an auto mixer tool like pavucontrol. It can optionally handle multimedia keys for controlling the audio volume.

packages.name: xfce4-screensaver
packages.descs: xfce4-screensaver (screen saver and locker for Xfce)
packages.descl: xfce4-screensaver is a screen saver and locker that aims to have simple, sane, secure defaults and be well integrated with the desktop.  This project is a port of MATE Screensaver. It has been tightly integrated with the Xfce desktop, utilizing Xfce libraries and the Xfconf configuration backend.

packages.name: xfce4-screenshooter
packages.descl: The screenshooter plugin adds a panel button that allows you to take screenshots.

packages.name: xfce4-session
packages.descl: Xfce4-session is a session manager for Xfce. Its task is to save the state of your desktop (opened applications and their location) and restore it during a next startup. You can create several different sessions and choose one of them on startup.

packages.name: xfce4-settings
packages.descl: xfce4-settings is the Xfce settings manager front-end. It comes with several different components for configuring application-independent settings inside xfconf.

packages.name: xfce4-systemload-plugin
packages.descs: xfce4-systemload-plugin (systemload plugin for the Xfce panel)
packages.descl: This plugin displays the current system load on the Xfce panel.

packages.name: xfce4-taskmanager
packages.descl: xfce4-taskmanager shows a list of running apps (similar to the task manager included with some other operating systems)  :)  The taskmanager is started by running the command 'xfce4-taskmanager'

packages.name: xfce4-terminal
packages.descl: This is the Xfce terminal emulator application. xfce4-terminal is a lightweight and easy to use terminal emulator for the X windowing system, with some new ideas and features that make it unique among X terminal emulators.

packages.name: xfce4-weather-plugin
packages.descs: xfce4-weather-plugin (weather plugin for the Xfce panel)
packages.descl: The weather plugin displays current weather conditions and forecasts.

packages.name: xfce4-whiskermenu-plugin
packages.descl: Whisker Menu is an alternate application launcher for Xfce. When you open it you are shown a list of applications you have marked as favorites. You can browse through all of your installed applications by clicking on the category buttons on the side. Top level categories make browsing fast, and simple to switch between. Additionally, Whisker Menu keeps a list of the last ten applications that you've launched from it.  Homepage: http://gottcode.org/xfce4-whiskermenu-plugin

packages.name: xfconf
packages.descl: A daemon and query system for managing the storage and retrieval of settings for the Xfce Desktop Environment, both graphically as well as from the command line.

packages.name: xfd
packages.descl: xfd displays all the characters in a font using either the X11 core protocol or libXft2.

packages.name: xfdesktop
packages.descl: Xfdesktop is a desktop manager for the Xfce Desktop Environment. Desktop in this respect means the root window. The manager handles tasks such as the background image and color, the root menu and window list, minimized application icons, and file icons on the desktop.

packages.name: xfig
packages.descl: This package contains the binary for xfig, an interactive drawing tool under X. Xfig can create fig, epsf, and LaTeX files with various options. You will also need the transfig package so that xfig can export fig files as epsf and LaTeX files. This package also contains a large set of example fig files.  Homepage: https://sourceforge.net/projects/mcj/files/

packages.name: xfontsel
packages.descl: xfontsel application provides a simple way to display the X11 core protocol fonts known to your X server, examine samples of each, and retrieve the X Logical Font Description ('XLFD') full name for a font.

packages.name: xfs
packages.descl: xfs is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xfsdump
packages.descs: xfsdump (backup tools for the XFS filesystem)
packages.descl: The xfsdump package contains the xfsdump and xfsrestore utilities for backing up and restoring XFS partitions. xfsdump examines files in a filesystem, determines which need to be backed up, and copies those files to a specified disk, tape or other storage medium. xfsrestore performs the inverse function of xfsdump; it can restore a full or incremental backup of a filesystem.

packages.name: xfsinfo
packages.descl: xfsinfo is a utility for displaying information about an X font server. It is used to examine the capabilities of a server, the predefined values for various parameters used in communicating between clients and the server, and the font catalogues and alternate servers that are available.

packages.name: xfsprogs
packages.descs: xfsprogs (tools to use the XFS filesystem)
packages.descl: XFS is a high performance journaling filesystem which originated on the SGI IRIX platform. It is completely multi-threaded, can support large files and large filesystems, extended attributes, variable block sizes, is extent based, and makes extensive use of Btrees (directories, extents, free space) to aid both performance and scalability.

packages.name: xfwm4
packages.descl: This package contains xfwm4 which is the window manager for Xfce4. It is designed to run with the rest of Xfce, but it also makes a capable window manager for any X11 environment.

packages.name: xgames
packages.descl: A few small and historic games and toys for X.  Includes maze, spider, xcolormap, xlander, xminesweep, xroach, xsnow.

packages.name: xgamma
packages.descl: xgamma allows X users to query and alter the gamma correction of a monitor via the X video mode extension (XFree86-VidModeExtension).

packages.name: xgc
packages.descl: xgc is an X11 graphics demo that shows various features of the X11 core protocol graphics primitives.

packages.name: xhost
packages.descl: xhost is used to manage the list of host names or user names allowed to make connections to the X server.

packages.name: xine-lib
packages.descl: xine-lib is a free (GPL licensed) high-performance multimedia playback engine. The xine shared libraries are used by xine-ui (and other media players and multimedia applications) for smooth video processing and playback of multimedia streams such as movies, radio and TV network streams, DVDs, and VCDs.  Homepage: https://www.xine-project.org/home

packages.name: xine-ui
packages.descs: xine-ui (xine multimedia playback engine user interface)
packages.descl: Xine is a free multimedia player. It plays back CDs, DVDs, and VCDs, multimedia files, and multimedia streamed over a network.  The xine-ui package contains the graphical user interface for the xine multimedia player.

packages.name: xinit
packages.descl: xinit is not intended for naive users. Instead, site administrators should design user-friendly scripts that present the desired interface when starting up X. The startx script is one such example.

packages.name: xinput
packages.descs: xinput (utility to configure and test X11 input devices)
packages.descl: xinput is a utility to configure and test XInput devices. It wasn't originally designed to be the primary tool for doing this but it's still pretty much the only program out there for doing it. :-)  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website: http://www.x.org

packages.name: xisxwayland
packages.descs: xisxwayland (determine if Xwayland is in use)
packages.descl: xisxwayland is a tool to be used within shell scripts to determine whether the X server in use is Xwayland. It exits with status 0 if the server is an Xwayland server and 1 otherwise. Any error results in an exit code of 3.

packages.name: xkbcomp
packages.descl: xkbcomp is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xkbevd
packages.descl: xkbevd is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xkbprint
packages.descl: xkbprint generates a printable or encapsulated PostScript description of an XKB keyboard description.

packages.name: xkbutils
packages.descl: xkbutils is a collection of small utilities utilizing the XKeyboard (XKB) extension to the X11 protocol.

packages.name: xkeyboard-config
packages.descl: The X Keyboard Extension essentially replaces the core protocol definition of keyboard. The extension makes possible to clearly and explicitly specify most aspects of keyboard behaviour on per-key basis and to more closely track the logical and physical state of the keyboard. It also includes a number of keyboard controls designed to make keyboards more accessible to people with physical impairments.

packages.name: xkill
packages.descl: xkill is a utility for forcing the X server to close connections to clients. This program is very dangerous, but is useful for aborting programs that have displayed undesired windows on a user's screen.

packages.name: xload
packages.descs: xload (displays a histogram of the system load average)
packages.descl: xload is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xlockmore
packages.descl: Patrick J. Naughton's xlock screensaver/locker for X, with many more modes added by David A. Bagley.  The 'Bob' bitmap has been included especially for Slackware, as well as a Linux penguin logo. (NOTE: the image of J. R. 'Bob' Dobbs is a registered trademark of The Subgenius Foundation, used by permission)  Homepage: http://sillycycle.com/xlockmore.html

packages.name: xlogo
packages.descs: xlogo (displays the X Window System logo)
packages.descl: xlogo is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xlsatoms
packages.descs: xlsatoms (lists the interned atoms defined on an X11 server)
packages.descl: xlsatoms is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xlsclients
packages.descs: xlsclients (X11 utility for listing X client info)
packages.descl: xlsclients is a utility for listing information about the client applications running on a X11 server.

packages.name: xlsfonts
packages.descs: xlsfonts (X11 font utility to list available fonts)
packages.descl: xlsfonts lists fonts available from an X server via the X11 core protocol.

packages.name: xmag
packages.descl: xmag displays a magnified snapshot of a portion of an X11 screen.

packages.name: xman
packages.descs: xman (graphical manual page browser using the Xaw toolkit)
packages.descl: xman is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xmessage
packages.descs: xmessage (displays a message or query in a window)
packages.descl: The user can click on an 'okay' button to dismiss it or can select one of several buttons to answer a question. xmessage can also exit after a specified time.

packages.name: xmh
packages.descl: The xmh program provides a graphical user interface to the MH Message Handling System. To actually do things with your mail, it makes calls to the MH package.

packages.name: xmms
packages.descl: XMMS is the X Multimedia System. It is used to play audio and other kinds of media files. By default XMMS can play MPEG audio, Ogg Vorbis, RIFF wav, most module formats, and a few other formats. XMMS can be extended through plugins to play a number of other audio and video formats.

packages.name: xmodmap
packages.descl: The xmodmap program is used to edit and display the keyboard modifier map and keymap table that are used by client applications to convert event keycodes into keysyms. It is usually run from a user's session startup script to configure the keyboard according to personal tastes.

packages.name: xmore
packages.descs: xmore (plain text display program for the X Window System)
packages.descl: xmore is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xorg-cf-files
packages.descl: The xorg-cf-files package contains the data files for the imake utility, defining the known settings for a wide variety of platforms (many of which have not been verified or tested in over a decade) and for many of the libraries formerly delivered in the X.Org monolithic releases.

packages.name: xorg-docs
packages.descl: This package provides miscellaneous documentation for the X Window System that doesn't better fit into other packages.  The preferred documentation format for these documents is DocBook XML.

packages.name: xorg-server
packages.descs: xorg-server (The Xorg server, the core of the X Window System)
packages.descl: Xorg is a full featured X server that was originally designed for UNIX and UNIX-like operating systems running on Intel x86 hardware. It now runs on a wider range of hardware and OS platforms.  This work was derived by the X.Org Foundation from the XFree86 Project's XFree86 4.4rc2  release. The XFree86 release was originally derived from X386 1.2 by Thomas Roell which was contributed to X11R5 by Snitily Graphics Consulting Service.  Homepage:  https://www.x.org

packages.name: xorg-server-xephyr
packages.descl: Xephyr is a nested X-Client like Xnest, but with some additional features like XRender support.

packages.name: xorg-server-xnest
packages.descl: Xnest is an experimental nested server for X that acts as both a client and a server. Xnest is a client of the real server which manages windows and graphics requests on its behalf.  Xnest is a server to its own clients. Xnest manages windows and graphics requests on their behalf. To these clients Xnest appears to be a conventional server.

packages.name: xorg-server-xvfb
packages.descl: Xvfb is an X server that can run on machines with no display hardware and no physical input devices. It emulates a dumb framebuffer using virtual memory. The primary use of this server is intended to be server testing. The mfb or cfb code for any depth can be exercised with this server without the need for real hardware that supports the desired depths. A secondary use is testing clients against unusual depths and screen configurations.

packages.name: xorg-server-xwayland
packages.descl: Wayland is a complete window system in itself, but even so, if we're migrating away from X, it makes sense to have a good backwards compatibility story. With a few changes, the Xorg server can be modified to use Wayland input devices for input and forward either the root window or individual top-level windows as wayland surfaces. The server still runs the same 2D driver with the same acceleration code as it does when it runs natively. The main difference is that Wayland handles presentation of the windows instead of KMS.

packages.name: xorg-sgml-doctools
packages.descl: This package provides a common set of SGML entities and XML/CSS style sheets used in building/formatting the documentation provided in other X.Org packages. It's typically only needed by people building from source who want to produce formatted documentation from their builds, or those who have installed the HTML version of the documentation, which refers to the included common xorg.css stylesheet.

packages.name: xorgproto
packages.descl: xorgproto is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xorriso
packages.descs: xorriso (ISO-9660 and Rock Ridge manipulation tool)
packages.descl: GNU xorriso is a command line and dialog application, which creates, loads, manipulates, and writes ISO-9660 file system images with Rock Ridge extensions. It can load the management information of existing ISO images and it writes the session results to optical media or to filesystem objects. Vice versa xorriso is able to copy file objects out of ISO 9660 filesystems.  Homepage: https://www.gnu.org/software/xorriso

packages.name: xpaint
packages.descl: XPaint is a versatile bitmap/pixmap editing tool with a feature set similar to MacPaint.  The short features list: Brushes, Spray paint, Pencil, Lines, Arcs, Pattern Fill, Text, Boxes, Circles, Polygons. Works on multiple images simultaneously. Cut/Copy/Paste between all active images. Fatbits/Zoom on the image windows.

packages.name: xpdf
packages.descl: Xpdf is a viewer for Portable Document Format (PDF) files.  xpdf was written by Derek B. Noonburg.

packages.name: xpr
packages.descs: xpr (dump an X window directly to a printer)
packages.descl: xpr takes as input a window dump file produced by xwd and formats it for output on various types of printers.

packages.name: xprop
packages.descs: xprop (displays window and font properties of an X server)
packages.descl: xprop is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xpyb
packages.descl: xpyb provides a Python binding to the X Window System protocol via libxcb.

packages.name: xrandr
packages.descl: Primitive command line interface to the X11 Resize, Rotate, and Reflect (RandR) extensions.

packages.name: xrdb
packages.descl: xrdb is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xrefresh
packages.descs: xrefresh (refresh all or part of an X screen)
packages.descl: xrefresh is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xsane
packages.descs: xsane (Graphical frontend to SANE, Scanner Access Now Easy)
packages.descl: xsane provides a graphical user-interface to control an image acquisition device such as a flatbed scanner. It allows previewing and scanning individual images and can be invoked either directly from the command-line or through the GIMP image manipulation program.  xsane accesses image acquisition devices through the SANE (Scanner Access Now Easy) interface.

packages.name: xscope
packages.descl: xscope is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xscreensaver
packages.descs: xscreensaver (a screen saver and locker for X)
packages.descl: A modular screen saver and locker for the X Window System. Highly customizable: allows the use of any program that can draw on the root window as a display mode. More than 100 display modes are included in this package.  Homepage: http://www.jwz.org/xscreensaver

packages.name: xset
packages.descs: xset (get and set various preferences and properties)
packages.descl: xset is a command line utility to get and set various preferences and properties for the current session.

packages.name: xsetroot
packages.descs: xsetroot (root window parameter setting utility for X)
packages.descl: xsetroot is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xsm
packages.descl: xsm is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xsnow
packages.descs: xsnow (let it snow on your desktop)
packages.descl: XSnow brings snow, trees, reindeer, Santa, and birds to your desktop.  Homepage: http://ratrabbit.nl/ratrabbit/xsnow/

packages.name: xstdcmap
packages.descl: The xstdcmap utility can be used to selectively define standard colormap properties. It is intended to be run from a user's X startup script to create standard colormap definitions in order to facilitate sharing of scarce colormap resources among clients using PseudoColor visuals.

packages.name: xterm
packages.descl: The xterm program is a terminal emulator for the X Window System. It provides DEC VT102/VT220 (VTxxx) and Tektronix 4014 compatible terminals for programs that cannot use the window system directly.

packages.name: xtrans
packages.descl: xtrans is a library of code that is shared among various X packages to handle network protocol transport in a modular fashion, allowing a single place to add new transport types. It is used by the X server, libX11, libICE, the X font server, and related components.

packages.name: xvidtune
packages.descl: xvidtune is a client interface to the X server video mode extension (XFree86-VidModeExtension).

packages.name: xvinfo
packages.descl: xvinfo prints out the capabilities of any video adaptors associated with the display that are accessible through the X-Video extension.

packages.name: xwd
packages.descs: xwd (dump an image of an X window)
packages.descl: xwd is part of X11.  For more information about the X.Org Foundation (the providers of the X.Org implementation of the X Window System), see their website:  http://www.x.org

packages.name: xwininfo
packages.descs: xwininfo (prints information about windows on an X server)
packages.descl: Various information is displayed depending on which options are selected.

packages.name: xwud
packages.descl: xwud allows X users to display in a window an image saved in a specially formatted dump file, such as produced by xwd.

packages.name: xxHash
packages.descl: xxHash is an Extremely fast Hash algorithm, running at RAM speed limits. It successfully completes the [SMHasher] (https://code.google.com/p/smhasher/wiki/SMHasher) test suite which evaluates collision, dispersion and randomness qualities of hash functions. Code is highly portable, and hashes are identical on all platforms (little / big endian).  Homepage: https://github.com/Cyan4973/xxHash

packages.name: xz
packages.descs: xz (compression utility based on the LZMA algorithm)
packages.descl: LZMA is a general purpose compression algorithm designed by Igor Pavlov as part of 7-Zip. It provides high compression ratio while keeping the decompression speed fast. XZ Utils are an attempt to make LZMA compression easy to use on free (as in freedom) operating systems.  The people most responsible for xz are Igor Pavlov, Ville Koskinen, and Lasse Collin. Homepage: http://tukaani.org/xz/

packages.name: yakuake
packages.descl: Yakuake is a drop-down terminal emulator based on KDE Konsole.  Some of the features of Yakuake include: Smoothly rolls down from the top of your screen Tabbed, skinnable interface Configurable dimensions and animation speed Sophisticated D-Bus interface

packages.name: yasm
packages.descs: yasm (complete rewrite of the NASM assembler)
packages.descl: Yasm is a complete rewrite of the NASM assembler under the 'new' BSD License (some portions are under other licenses, see COPYING for details). Yasm currently supports the x86 and AMD64 instruction sets, accepts NASM and GAS assembler syntaxes, outputs binary, ELF32, ELF64, 32 and 64-bit Mach-O, RDOFF2, COFF, Win32, and Win64 object formats, and generates source debugging information in STABS, DWARF 2, and CodeView 8 formats.  yasm home: http://www.tortall.net/projects/yasm/

packages.name: yptools
packages.descl: NIS stands for Network Information Service. NIS is usually used to provide /etc/passwd and /etc/group information throughout the network. Most Sun-based networks run NIS, and Linux machines can take full advantage of existing NIS service or provide NIS service themselves.

packages.name: ytalk
packages.descl: YTalk is a multi-user chat program. It works almost exactly like the UNIX talk program and even communicates with the same talk daemon, but YTalk allows for multiple connections.

packages.name: zanshin
packages.descl: Zanshin is a powerful yet simple application to manage your day to day actions. It helps you organize and reduce the cognitive pressure of what you have to do in your job and personal life. You'll never forget anything anymore, getting your mind like water. Zanshin's user interface lets you quickly see an overview of your life and tasks.  Homepage: https://zanshin.kde.org

packages.name: zd1211-firmware
packages.descl: This distribution contains the firmware files for the ZD1211 chip, which is used in WLAN USB sticks. The files are generated from C header files distributed in the original ZyDAS ZD1211 driver. The GPL-licensed header files used to produce the firmware blobs are also present in this distribution.  The full source of the original ZYDAS driver is available from http://zd1211.wiki.sourceforge.net/VendorDriver

packages.name: zeroconf-ioslave
packages.descl: A network monitor for DNS-SD services (Zeroconf).

packages.name: zerofree
packages.descs: zerofree (zero free blocks from ext* filesystems)
packages.descl: Zerofree finds the unallocated, non-zeroed blocks in an ext2, ext3, or ext4 filesystem and fills them with zeroes. This is useful if the device on which this file-system resides is a disk image. In this case, depending on the type of disk image, a secondary utility may be able to reduce the size of the disk image after zerofree has been run.  Homepage: https://frippery.org/uml/

packages.name: zlib
packages.descl: zlib is a general purpose thread safe data compression library. The data format used by the zlib library is described by RFCs 1950 to 1952 in the files ftp://ds.internic.net/rfc/rfc1950.txt (zlib format) rfc1951.txt (deflate format) and rfc1952.txt (gzip format).  Homepage: http://www.zlib.net

packages.name: zoo
packages.descl: Zoo is used to create and maintain collections of files in compressed form. It uses a Lempel-Ziv compression algorithm that gives space savings in the range of 20% to 80% depending on the type of file data. Zoo can store and selectively extract multiple generations of the same file. Data can be recovered from damaged archives by skipping the damaged portion and locating undamaged data with the help of fiz(1).  Zoo was written by Rahul Dhesi.

packages.name: zsh
packages.descl: Zsh is a UNIX command interpreter (shell) which of the standard shells most resembles the Korn shell (ksh), although it is not completely compatible. It includes enhancements of many types, notably in the command-line editor, options for customizing its behavior, filename globbing, features to make C-shell (csh) users feel more at home and extra features drawn from tcsh (another 'custom' shell). Zsh was written by Paul Falstad.

packages.name: zstd
packages.descl: Zstandard, or zstd for short, is a real-time compression algorithm providing high compression ratios. It offers a very wide range of compression/speed trade-off, while being backed by a very fast decoder. It also offers a special mode for small data, called dictionary compression, and can create dictionaries from any sample set.  Homepage: http://zstd.net/

locations.a: The base system. Contains software to get up and running and have a text editor and basic communications programs
locations.d: Program development tools. Compilers, debuggers, interpreters, and man pages. It's all here
locations.f: FAQs, HOWTOs, and other miscellaneous documentation
locations.xap: Applications that require X to run
locations.n: Networking programs. Daemons, mail programs, telnet, news readers, web servers and so on
locations.ap: Various applications that do not require the X Window System
